description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: February 25, 2020: With Bulletin N. 90, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended a meeting with EU Health Commissioner, Stella Kyriakides, and the Ministers of Health of those countries bordering with Italy: Austria, France, Slovenia and Switzerland. The Ministers of Health of Germany and Croatia also took part in the meeting. The aim of the meeting was to share and discuss information about the epidemiological situations of COVID-19 in the States. Issues about travelling and movement of goods between countries were also discussed.

description: December 15, 2020: With Bulletin N. 317, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health attended a meeting with other European States including Belgium, France, Germany, Luxembourg, The Netherlands, Spain and Switzerland. The aim of the meeting was to discuss the vaccination campaign and the need to coordinate efforts for the safe and efficient use of the COVID-19 vaccine. During the meeting, the Ministers agreed to promote the coordination of the vaccination campaign and the rapid sharing of information between national and international authorities. Furthermore, they agreed on a fast sharing of information and experiences in the field of pharmacovigilance. The Ministers also committed to fight disinformation and fake news over the vaccination campaign. Finally, the Health Ministers agreed on the need to ensure a clear and transparent communication to the population about vaccines.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: February 3, 2020: With Bulletin N. 42, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, attended a summit between G7 Health Ministers on COVID-19. Health Ministers include: Patricia A. Hajdu for Canada, Agnès Buzyn for France, Jens Spahn for Germany, Kato Katsunobu for Japan, Matt Hancock for the UK and Alex Michael Azar II for the US. The aim of the conference was to share information between Health Ministries of the G7. Updates about the trend of the pandemic and the epidemiological situation in each State were discussed. The Italian Minister of Health outlined to the G7 colleagues the measures taken by Italy, for example the ban of flights from China and health monitoring in ports and airports. The meeting also discussed the importance of a communal commitment to support the Chinese government in its efforts to address the emergency and underlined the need to collaborate and share all scientific information useful to fight COVID-19.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: February 12, 2020: With Bulletin N. 65, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, attended a teleconference between G7 Health Ministers on COVID-19 (Countries within the G7 include: Italy, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, USA and UK). The aim of the conference was to share information between Health Ministries of the G7. During the conference, updates were provided on the state of the epidemic in each State and on the measures taken by each State. Possible future scenarios were also examined. Finally, the Ministers discussed the procedures for the exchange of biological material in order to share all the information in the field of scientific research.

description: April 3, 2020: With Bulletin N. 135, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, attended a summit with G7 Health Ministers on COVID-19 (Countries within the G7 include: Italy, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, USA and UK). The aim of the conference was to share information about the COVID-19 health crisis between Health Ministries of the G7. During the conference, updates were provided on the state of the epidemic in each country and on the measures taken by each State. During the meeting, a common problem that emerge was the need to improve the validation of serological tests and the use of the most modern technologies for 'fast tracking'. The Italian Minister said that the G7 countries need a common approach to the same issues and that international collaboration is vital.

description: On the 19 March 2020, the Prefecture of the Region of Grand Est in France published an online article rebutting misinformation about Covid-19 (including scams and fradulent cures) which had appeared online, and reiterating the correct health responses and procedures.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 20th, Lyon published an announcement warning against scammers taking advantage of the Covid-19 pandemic, including those selling hand sanitizer at prices higher than the national fixed price. The city "reminds individuals that there does not currently exist any vaccine, food, air purifier, lamp, dietary supplement, or any other product that protects from or cures COVID 19." The announcement also reminded readers that "COVID 19 tests are carried out by health authorities via medical prescription. No other organization or individual is allowed to process these tests."
The announcement warns that purchasing paracetamol online is illegal, and warns against scams of home decontamination procedures, stating that "no home decontamination procedures are scheduled by the government at this time. Those pretending to carry out a mandatory decontamination are unauthorized to do so and are looking to gain access into unsuspecting peoples' houses."
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: On April 2, 2020, the French Minister of the Interior confirmed that the digital attestation passes needed for travel outside of the home could not collect personal information. There had been concerns that the information provided was being collected by the government. The government confirmed that the digital attestation only provided the same information as the previous paper form of the attestation. None of the data would be transmitted to government servers and only work locally.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 6, 2020, the French national government issued statements, confirming that a map of dates when lockdown restrictions would be lifted was not from the government. The map was shared on social media and contained official logos of the French Ministry of Health. When contacted for comment, the office of the Prime Minister confirmed that the map was a hoax. The prefecture of Hauts-de-France et du Nord also published a statement on Twitter explaining that the map was fake and asking people not to continue sharing it. They asked that people follow official government accounts for information.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 22, 2020, the French Director General of Health, Jéròme Salomon, made a statement during a press conference advising people that a study suggesting nicotine preventing COVID-19 has not been proven. Although the minister did not rule out the possibility of nicotine preventing COVID-19, he cautioned the public to be mindful of the proven dangers of smoking. He warned people not to use nicotine as a treatment at this time. The Minister of Health, Olivier Véran, made a similar statement advising people not to self-medicate.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 30, 2020, the French government agency, SIG (Service of government information) created a webpage entitled "Desinfox" to combat misinformation ("fake news") about COVID-19. The site was meant to fact check news articles and provide reliable information on the pandemic to citizens. The government said the site would be taken down after the COVID crisis ended.

description: On May 27, 2020, the French Health Ministry forbade the use of the drug hydroxychloroquine in COVID-19 patients based on new studies showing that it had no benefit and might cause adverse health effects. The use of hydroxychloroquine to prevent COVID-19 had been promoted by high-profile figures.

description: On January 26, 2021, in a press release, INSERM (the French National Institute of Health and Medical Research) published a review of ivermectin's potential as a treatment against COVID-19. Ivermectin is a medication used to treat parasitic infections. Using ivermectin to treat COVID is being promoted online. INSERM concluded that studies performed up to this point are no sufficient to show that ivermectin is able to treat or prevent COVID and recommended against its use.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 2, 2021, the French national government republished information from the Corsica Regional Health Agency on how to combat disinformation related to the COVID-19 pandemic. The government website provides a list of reputable information sources, including links to the French government's coronavirus page, the Ministry of Health, the French Public Health website, the Pasteur Institute, the World Health Organization, the Ministry for Travel, the Ministry for Education, the Ministry for Europe and Foreign Affairs, and SantéBD (a site that provides comprehensible information about COVID to the public). The government website also provides several graphics addressing common misconceptions about COVID (ex. drinking hot liquid cannot kill the virus, despite claims).

France’s education minister, Jean-Michel Blanquer, said around 120 schools have been ordered to close, most in Brittany and the Oise region north of Paris, which have been hit hard by COVID-19, the disease caused by the new coronavirus. Tens of thousands of students sent home.

description: From March 9, 2020, the prefects of Corsica and Corse-du-Sud in France announced that schools in Ajaccio are closed until March 22, 2020. On March 12, 2020 the prefect of Corse-du-Sud, in conjunction with the rector of the academic region of Corsica, extended the region affected by school closures beyond the Ajaccio city limits, closing additional schools and colleges located in the greater Ajaccio area. All schools within these areas remain closed until Sunday March 22, 2020 UPDATE: On March 12, the geographical target of this policy changed as the prefect of southern Corsica, in conjunction with the rector of the academic region of Corsica, decided on Thursday 12 March to close additional schools and colleges located in the greater Ajaccio area rather than just in the city, until Sunday March 22. UPDATE: On March 12, the geographical target of this policy changed as the prefect of southern Corsica, in conjunction with the rector of the academic region of Corsica, decided on Thursday 12 March to close additional schools and colleges located in the greater Ajaccio area rather than just in the city, until Sunday March 22.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: On March 3, 2020, both primary and secondary schools have been shut in the Oise department north of Paris and in Brittany, where the main clusters of French cases have emerged, and where two people who have died of the virus lived.  France’s education minister, Jean-Michel Blanquer, said around 120 schools have been ordered to close, most in Brittany and the Oise region north of Paris, which have been hit hard by COVID-19, the disease caused by the new coronavirus. Tens of thousands of students sent home. UPDATE: On March 14, 2020 France "ordered the closure of all schools" starting March 16, 2020.

description: On May 5th 2020, the Mayor of Paris in France announced the city's deconfinement plan highlighting strict sanitary protocols for students returning to school starting the week of May 11th 2020 which would be published on France's Ministry of National Education's website. This policy was implemented in line with France's national deconfinement policy. These measures consist of classrooms being disinfected before reopening, strict schedules put into place at the beginning of school days, if possible separate entrances for student arrivals, no more than 16 pupils in a room of 50 m2, desks should be placed at least one meter apart in classrooms, social distancing during recess, frequent ventilation of rooms every 10 minutes, disinfection of common areas, masks are mandatory for staff, and recommended, but not mandatory for primary school students.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Regular cleaning and sanitary procedures applied to classrooms (e.g. classrooms must be aired out after each class) ,Other conditions not listed above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

Pre-schools (maternelles) and primary schools will reopen from May 11, secondary schools will reopen from May 18. description: 18 May, 2020. 8 schools in northern France close due to cases. Schools only began reopening in France last week, but seven public institutions and one private school in Roubaix closed on Monday morning. The decision was made after one child in reception class contracted Covid-19. Local authorities said the most of the affected schools will be able to reopen by May 25. It was not confirmed whether the 70 or so cases were among staff or pupils.

description: On May 19, 2020, the Rectorate of the Ile-de-France region of France with the support of the regional prefect, departmental prefects, state services, ARS (Regional Health Agency) and communities have defined a common protocol for the reopening of schools. The strict health protocol is broken down into 3 stages: 1) Make an inventory of reception, sanitary and logistical conditions in all establishments, 2) Define an educational reception plan and logistics organization and 3) Develop a prioritization plan for audiences based on the possible mobilization of staff.

description: In France, starting on June 2 2020, technical high schools will be allowed to reopen in the orange regions of Ile-de-France, French Guiana, and Mayotte. Professional and general high schools will remain closed. Attendance is voluntary. Masks are mandatory. Classes are limited to 15 students.

description: In France from May 18, 2020, middle schools can reopen in green departments only, starting with sixième (age 11) and cinquième (age 12). Classes sizes are limited to only 15 students per class and masks are mandatory for all faculty and students. UPDATE: The original reopening of middle schools applied to only green departments. However, starting June 2, middle schools will reopen in all departments in France, regardless of color designation.

description:
On May 19, 2020, the Rectorate of the Ile-de-France region of France, with the support of the regional prefect, departmental prefects, state services, ARS (Regional Health Agency) and communities have defined a common protocol for the reopening of schools. It was announced that the health security will be ensured for staff and students through the means of mask wearing, social distancing, classes limited to 15 students, and any student not in school would follow online distanced learning. UPDATE: Starting June 2, 2020, the île-de-France region of France decided that:

- "All primary schools reopen but with reduced numbers, no more than 15 students per class and must ensure a systematic reception of students, at least part of the week.

- Colleges: it is the turn of the 6th and 5th grades to gradually return to college. Masks are mandatory when travelling within establishments.

- Vocational high schools open their doors and general and technological high schools welcome students for individual pedagogical interviews. Masks are mandatory when travelling."

These measures are part of the second phase of deconfinement in the orange zone.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Other conditions not listed above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: 01.12.2021 in France, the French National Government has announced that as soon as a positive case is detected, all the students in the class are then immediately tested. If the test is positive, the student becomes a confirmed case and must isolate for 10 days. If the test is negative, the student can then continue the face-to-face classes.

description: According to the Minister of Education of France, from January 14, 2021, the government would roll out a mass-testing scheme in schools, testing up to one million pupils and teachers each month: "Every time there are three cases (discovered), a screening team will be sent to the premises". In the canteens, pupils in the same class will eat together every day and at the same table. High school pupils in terminale (third and final year) would have to be present “as much as possible”. The government announced that all indoor sports were temporarily suspended. This includes out-of-school activities. First-year university students will be authorised to return to their courses on-site, but with reduced numbers of participants, from January 25th.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Negative COVID-19 Test,Other Health Monitoring
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: France is to reopen its universities on 25 January 2021, prime minister Jean Castex has declared, after nearly four months of lockdown to reduce coronavirus infections.  The plan to return to face-to-face teaching was announced during a televised press conference on 14 January. From 25 January—Monday next week—half of the country’s first-year students will resume attending classes on campuses, Castex announced.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
institution_status: Higher education institutions allowed to open with no conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: France is to reopen its universities on 25 January 2021, prime minister Jean Castex has declared, after nearly four months of lockdown to reduce coronavirus infections. Instead, distance learning for all students will take place from April 6, 2021 until April 9, 2021 before their two week Easter holiday (April 10, 2021 - April 25, 2021).This measure also applies to out-of-school establishments, but does not apply to medico-social structures supporting children with disabilities.

description: From June 17, 2021, French elementary schools open, middle and high schools alternate childrens attendance 50% online, 50% in person. Higher education open with 50% staffing. Masks required in and around schools but not in playgrounds, barrier measures in place, 2-meter distancing between students in canteens, improved ventilation in schools. UPDATE: On July 28, France announced that it would replace this regulation with a four-tier system of restrictions.

description: On July 28, 2021, the Minister for National Education of France announced a new policy for middle and high schools to be implemented from the start of the new school year on September 2. A four-tier system of restrictions will be in place with controls depending on the incidence of COVID-19. Level 1 (Green): In-person learning at all levels. Level 2 (Yellow): In-person learning at all levels. Level 3 (Orange): In-person learning at primary and middle schools, hybrid learning (alternating distance and in-person learning) in high schools. Level 4 (Red): In-person learning in primary schools, hybrid learning for 50% of 3rd year, all 4th year and high school students. Increasing levels of sanitary requirements, mask-wearing, restrictions on sports, and protocols for contact tracing will be applied at each level.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Following the French National Authority for Health (HAS) recommendations, the French national government announced on the 3rd of December 2020 its Covid-19 vaccination strategy, which applies to all of France: 
- Phase 1 will target individual living in residential accommodations for dependent elderly people (E.H.P.A.D) as well as the staff.
- Phase 2 will target individuals over 75 years old, in the 64-75 age range, healthcare professionals over 50 and/or immunocompromised healthcare professionals.
- Phase 3 will target all the rest of the population, with a focus on individuals between the ages of 50 and 64, as well as individuals working in essential sectors (education,security and services).

description: After the vaccination of an initial 1 million people in January 2021 in France, an additional 14 million at high risk for coronavirus infection will be inoculated beginning in February 2021. France has ordered 200 million doses from different pharmaceutical companies developing vaccines, enough to inoculate 100 million people - more than France's population of just over 66 million. According to the Prime Minister of the country, Jean Castex, vaccination will be voluntary and free of charge.

description: On December 5, 2020, French Prime Minister Jean Castex outlined a national vaccination plan during a news conference late Thursday, in accordance with the High Authority for Health. It will start January 1, 2021 with a free shot to everyone. France has ordered 1 million doses from the three different companies who have vaccine candidates: Pfizer, along with BioNTech, Moderna, both US-based, and AstraZeneca, based in the UK. The 1 million elderly who live in care homes will be the first to receive it, followed by health care workers employed in nursing homes and, importantly, those who transport them, then the elderly population. A second vaccination campaign will follow in February where the vaccine will be given to those older than 75, then 65 to 74 with a co-morbidity, then to those in the age group without. Following that, anyone in the health and medical fields older than 50 will receive the shot. The general population will then receive the vaccine in the spring, from the eldest to the most vulnerable, followed by the remainder of the population.

description: From the 2nd of January, French medical staff over 50 will begin to be vaccinated (which had previously been planned for February), to speed up the vaccination roll out. The reason for this is a much slower debut of the vaccination campaign than most other European countries: as of December 31, 2020, only 352 people in France had gotten at least one dose of the vaccine, versus 131,626 in Germany and 944,539 in the U.K., according to data cited by Le Parisien.

description:
Following the French National Authority for Health (HAS) recommendations, the French national government announced on the 3rd of December 2020 its Covid-19 vaccination strategy, which applies to all of France: 
- Phase 1 will target individual living in residential accommodations for dependent elderly people (E.H.P.A.D) as well as the staff.
- Phase 2 will target individuals over 75 years old, in the 64-75 age range, healthcare professionals over 50 and/or immunocompromised healthcare professionals.
- Phase 3 will target all the rest of the population, with a focus on individuals between the ages of 50 and 64, as well as individuals working in essential sectors (education,security and services). UPDATE: Originally, the second phase of the COVID-19 vaccination strategy (vaccinating people having a risk factor, chronic illnesses, etc.) was supposed to be held from February to spring 2021. On January 14 2021, the French national government announced that individuals of all ages that are at high risk of contracting the virus will be allowed to get vaccinated starting from the 18th of January 2020. This will include individuals who have severe medical issues such as cancer, hematological diseases that need chemotherapy treatment, chronic illnesses, organ transplants, transplanted by allogeneic  hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, chronic multiple pathologies and presenting at least two organ failure and Down's syndrome.

description:
First delivery of doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine to France will take place on February 6, 2021. After receiving a European marketing authorization on January 29, 2021, the vaccine developed by the firm AstraZeneca was the subject of a recommendation from the High Authority for Health (HAS). This vaccine is administered in two doses and can prevent severe forms of COVID 19 in people aged 18 and over. At this stage, the HAS recommends this vaccine:
- in people under 65, starting with professionals in the health or medico-social sector, regardless of their age;
- and in people aged 50 to 64, prioritizing those with comorbidities. 
273,600 doses will be distributed from today between 117 establishments, including 7 overseas. The next delivery will take place next week (304,800 doses) .

description:
Following the French National Authority for Health (HAS) recommendations, the French national government announced on the 3rd of December 2020 its Covid-19 vaccination strategy, which applies to all of France: 
- Phase 1 will target individual living in residential accommodations for dependent elderly people (E.H.P.A.D) as well as the staff.
- Phase 2 will target individuals over 75 years old, in the 64-75 age range, healthcare professionals over 50 and/or immunocompromised healthcare professionals.
- Phase 3 will target all the rest of the population, with a focus on individuals between the ages of 50 and 64, as well as individuals working in essential sectors (education,security and services). UPDATE: Originally, Phase 3 (vaccinating professionals in essential sectors, people aged 50 to 64, etc.) was supposed to launch in spring 2021. From the 6th of February 2021, throughout France, vaccination is allowed for all health and social sector professionals, private nurses and firefighters regardless of their age.

description:
Since the 12th of February 2021, doctors are allowed to vaccinate their patients between the ages of 50 and 64 years old, including those with severe illnesses, with the Astrazeneca vaccine. 10 vials of the AstraZeneca vaccine will be available at a local pharmacy to doctors willing to vaccinate. Each doctor would need to choose a dispensary between the 15th of February 2021 and the 17th of February 2021. The chosen pharmacy will be working with the doctor perpetually. This process does not require the registration of the practitioner's name and RPPS number in the tele-declaration portal. Volunteer doctors are therefore invited to approach the pharmacy of their choice as soon as possible. UPDATE: Since the 25th of February 2021, doctors that do not exclusively work in hospitals (private doctors and salaried doctors) have the possibility to vaccinate their 50 to 64-year-old patients with the AstraZeneca vaccine. These patients should have diseases that put them at severe risk of catching Covid-19. This decision, made in accordance with the French National Authority for Health (HAS), was released on the 2nd of February 2021. From March 2, doctors can
now also offer vaccination with the AstraZeneca vaccine:
- to their patients aged 65 to 74 when they have comorbidities with risk factors for forms severe from COVID. 
- to all their patients aged 75 and over.

description: According to the decree of March 4, 2021, midwives in France can prescribe vaccines to any person, including women, those close to pregnant women and children during the postnatal period, with the exception of people with a history of an anaphylactic reaction to one of the components of these vaccines or having presented an anaphylactic reaction during the first injection. Community pharmacists, mutualist pharmacies and mining emergency pharmacies can prescribe vaccines to any person, except pregnant women, people with a hemostasis disorder and people with a history of anaphylactic reactions.

description:
"In accordance with decree n ° 2021-325 of March 26, 2021, the following groups below can participate in the vaccination campaign by administering vaccines in vaccination centers around France: 
- students in their 3rd cycle of medical school.
- students in their 3rd cycle of pharmacy provided that they have followed either the
theory and practice relating to vaccination as part of their course.
- individuals studying in the field of healthcare provided that they have followed either the theory and practice relating to vaccination as part of their cours
- students in their 2nd or 3rd cycles of dentistry, in the presence of a doctor or nurse. They also need to have gone training, certified by healthcare professionals trained in vaccine administration. 
- students in their 2nd cycle of medical school or pharmacy. 
- students in their first cycle of medical school having completed their nursing internship, in the presence of a doctor or nurse. They also need to have training certified by healthcare professionals trained in vaccine administration.

description: On the 11th of March 2021, Janssen/Johnson and Johnson is authorised for use alongside Pfizer, Moderna and AstraZeneca. This is in adherence with EU policy. It now includes people between the ages of 55 and 69, whether they suffer from comorbidities or are at high risk of developing Covid-19 or not as well as people aged 70 and over.

description: Between the 12th and 13th of April 2021, ordering the Janssen vaccine will be possible for doctors, pharmacists, nurses through an online platform. They will need to order them through the same dispensary they used for the Astrazeneca vaccine and are only allowed 1 vial of 5 doses due to the limited number of the Janssen vaccine availability in France. All orders will be delivered between the 12th and 13th of April 2021.

description: On March 17, 2021, the European Commission has made the proposal for a “digital green certificate” whose objective is to allow, in a secure manner, the movement of people between the countries of the European Union. France is fully in line with this approach and is launching “TousAntiCovid Carnet” with test and vaccination certificates, starting April 19, 2021, that can be verified at national level, then by the other countries of the European Union, and terminates outside the borders of the European Union. The French Government is offering 3 types of certificates: the negative test certificate, the recovery from Covid-19 and the vaccination certificate.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19,People who are partially vaccinated against COVID-19,People who are not vaccinated against COVID-19

description:
On the 15th of February 2021, the French national government delivered 9190 doses of Pfizer vaccines to the island of The Reunion (an overseas territory of France).The French government decided to accelerate its vaccination programme in The Reunion and is looking to deliver 30420 additional doses before March. UPDATE: In order to promote the vaccination campaign in the French Overseas territories, Sébastien Lecornu, Minister of Overseas Territories, and Olivier Véran, Minister of Solidarity and Health, expand the vaccination campaign targets in some territories: 

- In Guadeloupe, Martinique, Guyana, Saint-Barthélémy, Saint-Martin, Saint-Pierre and Miquelon and Wallis and Futuna, vaccination is open to all people over 18 years old.
- In Mayotte, vaccination is open to all people over 16.
- In Reunion, from May 3, in addition to anyone over the age of 55, vaccination will also be open to people over 50 and to at risk people aged 45.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_vac_purchase: Preorder with the option of expanding the order
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
The vaccination campaign enters a new phase from May 1, 2021 in France: all people over 18 suffering from one or more co-morbidities as defined by the Ministry of Solidarity and Health and in accordance with the recommendations of the High Authority for Health, is able to get the Moderna or Pfizer vaccine. 

The list of comorbidities associated with a risk of severe form of Covid-19, defined by the Ministry of Solidarity and Health, following the recommendations of the Haute Autorité de Santé is as follows: cardiovascular pathologies; types 1 and 2 diabetes; chronic respiratory pathologies liable to decompensate during a viral infection; chronic renal failure; obesity with body mass index ≥30; cancer or malignant hemopathy; chronic liver disease, especially cirrhosis; congenital or acquired immunosuppression; major sickle cell syndrome or history of splenectomy; neurological pathologies; psychiatric disorders; dementia.

People aged 18 to 49 who suffer from comorbidities will therefore now be able to make an appointment at a vaccination according to the usual procedures in order to be vaccinated with the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna vaccines.

description: Starting from June 15, 2021, vaccination is open to the French population aged 12 to 17. For now, only the Pfizer BioNTech messenger RNA vaccine has marketing authorization for ages 12 and older. For the vaccination of minors, the authorization of both parents is required. In the event of the absence of one of the two parents, the parent present completes the certificate and undertakes on honor to have previously obtained the consent of the absent parent and co-holder of parental authority.

description: On December, 13, France has announced that people vaccinated with Janssen are eligible, regardless of age, for an additional dose of messenger RNA vaccine 1 month after their first injection. People who have been vaccinated with Janssen for more than 4 weeks are advised to receive this second dose as soon as possible. They have 8 weeks to complete this extra dose after their last Janssen injection. Since December 15, 2021, this additional dose has made it necessary to maintain their vaccination certificate under the “ sanitary pass .

description: In Hautmont, France (Hauts-de France region), from March 21until April 30, a curfew for unaccompanied minors is in place from 6pm to 6am. This applies to any general means of locomotion, including pedestrian, motor vehicle, bicycle, and scooter. In the event of an offense, the parents of the minor the National Police or the Gendarmerie will escort the minor home, and the parents will be charged a fine of 135 euros.

description:
"On 27th March 2020 the prefecture of Meurthe-et-Moselle announced that in all 20 municipalities of Grand Nancy the movement of any person is prohibited from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. with the exception of trips between home and the place (s) of professional activity and business trips unable to be deferred; travel for health reasons with the exception of consultations and care that can be provided remotely and, except for patients with a long-term illness, those that can be postponed; Travel for compelling family reasons, for the assistance of vulnerable people and for childcare; Travel for the sole purpose of participating in missions of general interest at the request of the administrative authority and in conditions it specifies.
These trips must be duly justified, by means of a document establishing that they are absolutely necessary during this time period

description: On October 22,2020, the French government declared that about 46 million inhabitants in France must be home by 9 p.m. to 6 a.m., following a strict nighttime curfew that entered into effect in 38 new departments this weekend. During that time people are only allowed out of their homes for essential reasons and everyone must carry a permission form stating their reason for being out. Breaking curfew can earn you a €135 fine or a €3,750 fine and six months in jail for repeat offenders.

description: The department Ardennes in France is enforcing a 6 week curfew from October 24 2020. People are not allowed to leave their house between 9pm and 6am with the following exceptions: movememnt between the home and school or work, consultations that cannot be done by distance, purchasing health products, helping vulnerable persons, movement of people with disabilities and their support worker, for a judicial or administrative summons, at the request of the administrative authority, movement to and from stations/airports for long distance travel, or brief movement within a 1km radius for their pet. Documentation is needed to permit movement with these exceptions

description: On the 24 Febraury 2020, the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the Grand Est region of France made a press release detailing a system of health monitoring for returned travellers. The management system targed returned travellers from the Veneto and Lombardy regions of Italy, mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau, Singapore and South Korea. If returned travellers displayed any symptoms, they were required to contact a centre for assessment and possible testing, and if confirmed ARS staff would trace close contacts. Positive cases were then instructed to self-isolate for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 25, 2020, the President of France signed Ordinance No. 2020-328, which extends by 180 days the period of validity of residence documents that are to expired between March 16, 2020 and May 15, 2020. description: As of March 17, the prefects of Corse-du-Sud and Haute-Corse issued orders drastically limiting the transportation of passengers by sea and air between mainland France and Corsica. These orders, going further than the national provisions, authorize the transport of passengers only for medical emergency, compelling family reasons, and professional travel on express prefectural authorization.

description: From March 17, 2020, the President of the Republic has announced a closure of the external borders of Europe and France for 30 days. French citizens are allowed to enter the country to return home, along with their spouse and children. This does not affect the exit from the national territory. There are exceptions for those who reside permanently in France.

description: As of March 16, 2020, France will stop issuing visas in all of its embassies and consulates abroad, until further notice. Affected by the decision are all types of visas, including short-stay Schengen visas, long-stay visas to France, visas to overseas territories, even ones for which an appointment had already been made. Visas granted to spouses of French nationals are not targeted.

description: From March 20th, 2020, unless an exemption has been granted by the representative of the competent state, cruise ships and passenger ships carrying more than 100 passengers are prohibited from making a stopover in Corsica, and from stopping over or anchoring in the internal waters and the territorial waters of the departments and regions of overseas, as well as Saint-Barthélemy and Saint-Martin, Saint-Pierre-et-Miquelon, and Wallis-et-Futuna. description:
From March 31, 2020, until April 15, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health mandated that it is forbidden, for any cruise ship, with or without passengers, to call, stop or anchor in French internal waters and territorial sea, unless otherwise permitted by the representative of the competent State. This policy does not apply to:
-maritime transport of internal security forces or emergency services and other means essential to the protection of the population, as well as of the armed forces essential to the ongoing missions of the ministry responsible for defence
-the reception of ships in difficulty or to ships having rescued people at sea
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From March 30, 2020, in France, for ships making international connections or connections of more than two hours, passengers must present to the maritime carrier, when they board, one or more documents to justify the reason for their trip, accompanied by a statement on the honor of this motif. Otherwise, boarding is refused. This policy is in effect until further notice.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
From March 20th, 2020, unless an exemption has been granted by the representative of the competent state, cruise ships and passenger ships carrying more than 100 passengers are prohibited from making a stopover in Corsica, and from stopping over or anchoring in the internal waters and the territorial waters of the departments and regions of overseas, as well as Saint-Barthélemy and Saint-Martin, Saint-Pierre-et-Miquelon, and Wallis-et-Futuna. Also, those ships are prohibited from stopping over in the French mainland ports in the Mediterranean, Atlantic, Channel and North Sea, until April 15. 
Update: Starting on March 31, 2020, unless otherwise granted by the representative of the competent State, it is prohibited, until April 15, 2020, for any cruise ship, with or without passengers, to stop over, stop or anchor in inland waters and the French territorial sea. UPDATE: The original policy targeted ships carrying more than 100 passengers. Now it applies to all ships with or without passengers and it concerns all France ports.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
From March 31, 2020, until April 15, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health mandated that it is forbidden, for any cruise ship, with or without passengers, to call, stop or anchor in French internal waters and territorial sea, unless otherwise permitted by the representative of the competent State. This policy does not apply to:
-maritime transport of internal security forces or emergency services and other means essential to the protection of the population, as well as of the armed forces essential to the ongoing missions of the ministry responsible for defence
-the reception of ships in difficulty or to ships having rescued people at sea
Update: The policy baring cruise ships to anchor or stop in French internal or territorial waters is extended until May 11, 2020. UPDATE: The policy baring cruise ships to anchor or stop in French internal or territorial waters was set to last until April 15 but is now extended until May 11.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From March 17, 2020, the President of the Republic has announced a closure of the external borders of Europe and France for 30 days. French citizens are allowed to enter the country to return home if they are entering from the Shengen Area and the UK, along with their spouse and children. This does not affect the exit from the national territory. There are exceptions for those who reside permanently in France. Update: The closure of borders to all foreign nationals that was set to expire on April 15 will be extended until indefinitely. UPDATE: The border closure for all foreign nationals, which was set to expire on April 15, 2020, was extended for an additional 30 days on April 11, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: From March 15, 2020, the Franco-German border restrictions will be strengthened in both directions. France has officially announced that it will strengthen controls at its border with Germany and limit border crossings to what is strictly necessary, allowing cross-border people and the transport of goods to pass. Beginning May 13th, 2020, the Franco-German border restrictions will remain in action until June 15, 2020 and new exemptions come into force for entry into French territory. Separated spouses are now allowed to cross the border to find each other. Border crossings justified by the exercise of the right of custody, visit or accommodation of a child or the pursuit of schooling, as well as the visit to a parent in an EHPAD or to a child in a specialized institution, are now also allowed. In addition, the documentation required to cross the Franco-German border will be simplified. UPDATE: new exemptions come into force for entry into French territory. An end date was also added.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
From 12 May 2020, in the French department of Haut-Rhin, the circulation of all vehicles and pedestrians is prohibited at certain land road crossing points with the territories of Germany and Switzerland. Crossing at the following crossing points is authorised, however is subect to time restrictions: Border crossings in Haut-Rhin are possible for authorized reasons at the following points: with Germany: at Vogelgrun (Brisachs bridge), Ottmarsheim (A36) and Village-Neuf (Palmrain bridge); - with Switzerland: in Sait-Louis (Lysbüchel, motorway and Bourgfelden), Hégenheim (Allschwil) and Leymen
(Benken), as well as by the Mulhouse - Basel rail line. From 20 May 2020 Haut-Rhin permits border crossings at Fessengheim and Huningue passerelle at the German border with authorisation. UPDATE: As of May 20, 2020 two new crossing points on the German border are now permitted: Crossing at the crossing points at Fessengheim and Huningue passerelle at the German border are now permitted with authorisation.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Beginning May 29, 2020, France is extending the validity of residency documents to those that hold residence permits that expire between March 16 and June 15 for a period of 90 days. The original order only applied to those whose permits would expire between March 16 and May 15. Those that hold these permits will hold validity for another 6 months until December 15.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Starting on May 11 2020, in France, maritime and fluvial transporters can ask passengers, before boarding, a sworn declaration attesting that he does not present any symptoms of covid-19 infection. Transporters can deny boarding to passengers who refuse to submit this declaration. UPDATE: On May 31 2020, in France, there has been a modification to the sworn declaration that could be asked by maritime and fluvial transporters.

description: On June 1st the French national government announced that, as of June 2nd 2020, inter-region travel is to resume as it had worked previously in the Île-de-France region while all borders with other European countries are to remain closed. This change comes after a previous closure of all inter-region travel throughout the country at the beginning of the pandemic.

description: 06.02.2020 in France, the French National Government has announced that travel to overseas territories is limited to people who can "justify an overriding health, family or professional reason." "On your arrival in Guadeloupe, Guyana, Reunion, Martinique, Saint-Martin, Saint-Barthélemy and Saint-Pierre-et-Miquelon, you are invited to remain isolated for 14 days, possibly in an accommodation."

description: Beginning June 15, 2020, travelers entering France from the European zone (EU Member States, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland, the Vatican and also travelers from the UK) will no longer have to present a travel certificate. All travelers from outside this area are still required to carry a travel certificate.

description: On June 12, 2020, in France, the foreign minister Jean-Yves Le Drian and the minister of the interior Christophe Castaner announce that from June 15, 2020, the travel restrictions and border closures in place since March 18, 2020, will remain for all countries except EU Member States as well as Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland and the Vatican. From July 1, 2020, France will start to reopen the borders to some non-Schengen countries.

description: As of April 8, 2020, at midnight, all travelers are required to fill out and carry a travel certificate according to their situation when entering the country. Update: Starting from June 15, 2020, this travel restriction is lifted and no longer required for travelers from countries in the European zone (EU Member States, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland and the Vatican). All travelers from outside this area are still required to carry a travel certificate. UPDATE: The originally policy required all travelers to provide a travel certificate when entering France, however this is no longer required from countries in the European zone (EU Member States, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland and the Vatican) starting from from 15 June.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: From March 17, 2020, the President of the Republic has announced a closure of the external borders of Europe and France for 30 days. French citizens are allowed to enter the country to return home if they are entering from the Shengen Area and the UK, along with their spouse and children. This does not affect the exit from the national territory. There are exceptions for those who reside permanently in France. UPDATE: On June 12, 2020, in France, the foreign minister Jean-Yves Le Drian and the minister of the interior Christophe Castaner announce that from June 15, 2020, people from EU Member States as well as Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland and the Vatican will be able to enter the country again as it had been the case before March 18, 2020.

description: From March 15th 2020, the Franco-German border restrictions will be strengthened in both directions. France has officially announced that it will strengthen controls at its border with Germany and limit border crossings to what is strictly necessary, allowing cross-border people and the transport of goods to pass. UPDATE: Starting June 15, 2020, "France will open its borders to all arrivals from the EU and nations that fall under the border-free Schengen zone. People arriving in the country from within Europe will not be put under quarantine. However, travelers from Britain will face the same two-week confinement that is mandatory for visitors to the UK."

description: As of March 16th, France will stop issuing visas in all of its embassies and consulates abroad, until further notice. Affected by the decision are all types of visas, including short-stay Schengen visas, long-stay visas to France, visas to overseas territories, even ones for which an appointment had already been made. Visas granted to spouses of French nationals are not targeted. UPDATE: Starting June 15,2020, France t will permit international students, whatever their country of origin, to come to France and the arrangements for their reception will be facilitated. Their visa and residence permit requests will be given priority.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: From March 30, 2020, in France, for ships making international connections or connections of more than two hours, passengers must present to the maritime carrier, when they board, one or more documents to justify the reason for their trip, accompanied by a statement on the honor of this motif. Otherwise, boarding is refused. This policy is in effect until further notice. UPDATE: Starting on July 11, 2020, in France, maritime and fluvial transporters can deny boarding to passengers who have refused to submit themselves to a temperature check. In addition, before boarding, passengers need to a sworn attestation that they don't have any symptoms od Covid-19 and they are not aware of having been in contact with a confirmed case of covid-19 in the fourteen days before.

description: On June 12, 2020, in France, the foreign minister Jean-Yves Le Drian and the minister of the interior Christophe Castaner announce that from June 15, 2020, the travel restrictions and border closures in place since March 18, 2020, will remain for all countries except EU Member States as well as Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland and the Vatican. From July 1, 2020, France will start to reopen the borders to some non-Schengen countries. UPDATE: The french secretary of state responsible for tourism announced a new exception to the travel restrictions starting August 8, 2020. Foreign nationals in relationships with French citizens will now be allowed to enter the French territory. To prove their relationship, they need to show proof of their partners French nationality, but also proof that the relationship is lasting and sentimental, for example by common bank accounts or invioces, rental lease agreements, passport stamps of frequent visits to the country.

description: Starting December 20, 2020, France closes all suspends all travel of people or transport of goods for at least 48 hours from the United Kingdom. Only unaccompanied freights are allowed.

description:
"From 23 December 2020 at zero o'clock and until 6 January 2021 inclusive, any person arriving in France from the United Kingdom presents, to the transport company, before boarding:

1. A declaration on his honor attesting that he does not have symptoms of covid-19 infection and that he is not aware of having been in contact with a confirmed case of covid-19 in the fourteen days preceding his journey;
2. If he is eleven years of age or older, the result of a test or a biological examination of virological screening carried out less than 72 hours before boarding does not conclude to contamination by covid-19. The only antigen tests that can be validly presented for the application of this 2° are those for the detection of the N protein of SARS-CoV-2.

[...] in the absence of presentation of these documents, boarding shall be denied and the person shall be escorted outside the spaces concerned."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People of a certain age (please note age range in the text entry)
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

UPDATE: The French Tourism Minister Jean-Baptiste Lemoyne announces that starting March 11, 2021, a compelling reason is no longer needed to travel to Australia, Israel, Japan, Singapore, South Korea, New Zealand and the United Kingdom.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Starting January 31, 2021, any entry to France from a country outside the European Union is forbidden. In addition, exit to countries outside the European Union is prohibited. Travel for compelling reasons is ecepted. UPDATE: In a decree to be published on Friday 12 March in France, "it will no longer be necessary to have a compelling reason to travel to or from Australia, Israel, Japan, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea or the United Kingdom due to the very wide dissemination of the British variant in France and the specific health situation in those countries.

For travel to and from those countries, other restrictions on movement remain in force: among other things, it is of course still necessary to present a negative PCR test result less than 72 hours before departure." It is strongly advised to limit international travel as much as possible.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: 04.22.2021 in France, the French National Government has announced that from 04.24.2020 a reinforced control system will be put in place for people arriving from Brazil, Argentina, Chile, South Africa and India: the list of reasons authorizing an arrival in France will be further restricted; the carrying out of a test will be systematized not only at departure but also on arrival and, above all, each person will then be subject to a strict quarantine decided by prefectural decree and accompanied by checks by law enforcement agencies.

description:
Starting March 25, 2020, the validity of residence documents (long-stay visas, residence permits, temporary residence permits, permit application receipts and asylum application certificates) are extended for a period of 90 days. The period of extension applies to the validity of residence permits that expire between March 16 and May 15. 
On April 22, 2020, the extension of residency document validity for documents set to expire between March 16 and May 15 has been extended for another 3 months period, for a total extension of now 6 months. UPDATE: There has been an extension to who the permit validity applies to.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_what: Foreign Residents (Foreign Nationals Residing in the Country)

description: After March 11, 2021 travel to as well as from France to any country except EU member states, Australia, Israel, Japan, Singapore, South Korea, New Zealand and the United Kingdom is still prohibited with the if not for compelling reasons. UPDATE: As announced on April 29, 2021, France decided on June 2, 2021, that "foreign tourists from outside the EU will be able to enter France on June 9." Foreign nationals from non-EU countries will be able to enter depending on their health status in their home country (classified as "green," "orange," or "red") and their vaccination status.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On June 2, 2021, France classified the following countries as "green" countries for which urgent reasons for entry are not required and which require a negative antigen/PCR test carried out less than 72 hours ago for unvaccinated travelers entering France:
European Area, Australia, Israel, Japan, Lebanon, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea

description:
On June 2, 2021, France classified the following countries as "orange" countries for which 
- urgent reasons are required for entry into France and the country of destination for unvaccinated persons only
- requiring a negative antigen test carried out less than 48 hours ago or PCR test carried out less than 72 hours ago for vaccinated and unvaccinated persons prior to boarding
- antigen testing for unvaccinated persons upon arrival, and voluntary self-isolation for 7 days for unvaccinated persons upon entry into France:
All countries except those classified as "green" and "red".

Entry requirements for orange countries depend on their regulations.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
On June 2, 2021, France classified the following countries as "red" countries for which

- urgent reasons are required for entry into France and the country of destination,

-there is a requirement for a negative antigen/PCR test carried out less than 48 hrs ago for vaccinated and unvaccinated persons prior to boarding, 

-antigen testing for vaccinated and unvaccinated persons upon arrival is needed

-and voluntary self-isolation for 7 days for vaccinated persons upon entry into France and mandatory 10-day quarantine supervised by security forces is required:

Argentina, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, India, Nepal, Pakistan, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Suriname, Turkey, Uruguay

Entry requirements for "red" countries depend on their regulations.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: After March 11, 2021 travel to as well as from France to any country except EU member states, Australia, Israel, Japan, Singapore, South Korea, New Zealand and the United Kingdom is still prohibited with the if not for compelling reasons. UPDATE: As announced on April 29, 2021, France decided on June 4, 2021, that "foreign tourists from outside the EU will be able to enter France on June 9." Foreign nationals from non-EU countries will be able to enter depending on their health status in their home country (classified as "green," "orange," or "red") and their vaccination status.

description: Starting January 24, 2021, any per over the age of 11, entering France from Algeria, Argentina, Armenia, Aruba, Bahamas, Belize, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Brazil, Cape Verde, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Guyana, India, Iraq, Israel, Kosovo, Kuwait, Lebanon, Libya, Madagascar, Maldives, Mexico, Moldova, Montenegro, Oman, Paraguay, Peru, Qatar, Serbia, Palestinian Territories, Turkey or Ukraine must present a negative PCR test not older than 72 hours upon arrival. UPDATE: As announced on April 29, 2021, France decided on June 2, 2021, that "foreign tourists from outside the EU will be able to enter France on June 9." Foreign nationals from non-EU countries will be able to enter depending on their health status in their home country (classified as "green," "orange," or "red") and their vaccination status. The status also determines if and when a PCR test must be performed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On June 23, 2021, France classified the following countries as ""green"" countries for which urgent reasons for entry are not required and which require a negative antigen/PCR test carried out less than 72 hours ago for unvaccinated travelers entering France:
Australia, South Korea, Israel, Lebanon, New Zealand, and Singapore, United States, Canada, Japan, European Union and Schengen Area countries.
Whereas the countries United States, Canada, Japan are new on the list.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
On June 23, 2021, France classified the following countries as ""orange"" countries for which 
- urgent reasons are required for entry into France and the country of destination for unvaccinated persons only
- requiring a negative antigen test carried out less than 48 hours ago or PCR test carried out less than 72 hours ago for vaccinated and unvaccinated persons prior to boarding
- antigen testing for unvaccinated persons upon arrival, and voluntary self-isolation for 7 days for unvaccinated persons upon entry into France:

All countries except those classified as "green" and ""red".

Entry requirements for orange countries depend on their regulations.

description:
As of July 17, 2021 France decided to lift the constraints on travelers benefiting from a complete vaccination schedule with a vaccine recognized by the European Medicines Agency (Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca or Janssen) as of Saturday, July 17, regardless of the country of origin. However, it is strongly discouraged to travel to a red country.
"The vaccination schedule is now considered complete, for anyone traveling to the France, after the injection of 2 doses (or one dose for people who have already contracted the virus) and a period of 7 days, against 14 days previously. For Janssen single-dose vaccine, the schedule remains complete after injection and a period of 28 days."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: People who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19

description:
"On June 23, 2021, France classified the following countries as ""red"" countries for which

- urgent reasons are required for entry into France and the country of destination,

-there is a requirement for a negative antigen/PCR test carried out less than 48 hrs ago for vaccinated and unvaccinated persons prior to boarding, 

-antigen testing for vaccinated and unvaccinated persons upon arrival is needed

-and voluntary self-isolation for 7 days for vaccinated persons upon entry into France and mandatory 10-day quarantine supervised by security forces is required:

Argentina, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, India, Namibia, Nepal, Pakistan, Russia, Seychelles, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Suriname, Turkey, Uruguay.
Whereas the countries Russia, Namibia and Seychelles are new on the list.

Entry requirements for ""red"" countries depend on their regulations." UPDATE: On July 18, 2021 France added Tunisia, Mozambique, Cuba and Indonesia to countries classified as "red". Constraints on travelers benefiting from a complete vaccination schedule with a vaccine recognized by the European Medicines Agency (Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca or Janssen) will be lifted as of Saturday, July 17, regardless of the country of origin. For unvaccinated travelers traveling from "red" countries, "they must, in accordance with the rules in force, be able to justify a compelling reason, present proof of test on departure, and comply with the obligation to test on arrival, as well as observe a controlled quarantine of 10 days once on French soil."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

Entry requirements for orange countries depend on their regulations. UPDATE: On July 17, 2021 France lifted constraints on travelers benefiting from a complete vaccination schedule with a vaccine recognized by the European Medicines Agency (Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca or Janssen), regardless of the country of origin.

description:
On July 18, 2021 France added Tunisia, Mozambique, Cuba and Indonesia to countries classified as "red". 
Countries classified as "red" currently are: Argentina, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, India, Namibia, Nepal, Pakistan, Russia, Seychelles, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Suriname, Turkey, Uruguay, Tunisia, Mozambique, Cuba, Indonesia

For unvaccinated travelers traveling from "red" countries, "they must, in accordance with the rules in force, be able to justify a compelling reason, present proof of test on departure, and comply with the obligation to test on arrival, as well as observe a controlled quarantine of 10 days once on French soil."
Constraints on travelers benefiting from a complete vaccination status was lifted on July 17, regardless of the country of origin.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: France announced the public health measures which applicable to all travellers leaving or entering France. From the 13 August 2021, if you are not vaccinated and you arrive from a "red" country: You can only travel to France if you have pressing grounds for travel. Upon boarding, each traveller aged 12 and over must present a negative PCR or antigenic test taken less than 48 hours before the flight. If you have previously contracted COVID-19, instead of a negative test result you may present a certificate of recovery dated more than 11 days and less than 6 months prior to the date of arrival. A certificate of recovery is a document issued to persons who have contracted COVID-19, upon presentation of a positive RT-PCR or antigenic test. Then you will be tested when you arrive in France. You will be subject to a mandatory 10-day quarantine supervised by security forces.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
On July 18, 2021 France added Tunisia, Mozambique, Cuba and Indonesia to countries classified as "red". 
Countries classified as "red" currently are: Argentina, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, India, Namibia, Nepal, Pakistan, Russia, Seychelles, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Suriname, Turkey, Uruguay, Tunisia, Mozambique, Cuba, Indonesia

For unvaccinated travelers traveling from "red" countries, "they must, in accordance with the rules in force, be able to justify a compelling reason, present proof of test on departure, and comply with the obligation to test on arrival, as well as observe a controlled quarantine of 10 days once on French soil."
Constraints on travelers benefiting from a complete vaccination status was lifted on July 17, regardless of the country of origin. UPDATE: From the 13 August 2021, if you are not vaccinated and you arrive from a "red" country:
- You can only travel to France if you have pressing grounds for travel.

- Upon boarding, each traveller aged 12 and over must present a negative PCR or antigenic test taken less than 48 hours before the flight.

- If you have previously contracted COVID-19, instead of a negative test result you may present a certificate of recovery dated more than 11 days and less than 6 months prior to the date of arrival.

- A certificate of recovery is a document issued to persons who have contracted COVID-19, upon presentation of a positive RT-PCR or antigenic test.- travelers will be tested when they arrive in France.

- Travelers will be subject to a mandatory 10-day quarantine supervised by security forces.

Countries currentyl classified as "red" are: Afghanistan, Argentina, Bangladesh, Brazil, Costa-Rica, Cuba, Democratic Republic of Congo, Indonesia, Maldives, Mozambique, Namibia, Nepal, Oman, Pakistan, Russia, Seychelles, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Suriname and Tunisia

Whereas the countries Afghanistan, Democratic Republic of Congo, Maldives and Oman are new on the list and Bahrain, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Turkey, Uruguay were removed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On June 2, 2021, France classified the following countries as ""orange"" countries for which 
- urgent reasons are required for entry into France and the country of destination for unvaccinated persons only
- requiring a negative antigen test carried out less than 48 hours ago or PCR test carried out less than 72 hours ago for unvaccinated persons prior to boarding
- random antigen testing for unvaccinated persons upon arrival, and self-isolation for 7 days for unvaccinated persons upon entry into France:

All countries except those classified as ""green"" and ""red" UPDATE: On August 13, 2021, the list of countries classified as "orange" was updated. Also, if the traveler has previously contracted COVID-19, instead of a negative test result they may present a certificate of recovery dated more than 11 days and less than 6 months prior to the date of arrival. A certificate of recovery is a document issued to persons who have contracted COVID-19, upon presentation of a positive RT-PCR or antigenic test.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: 02.28.2020 in France, the French National Government has announced that for unvaccinated or not fully vaccinated people, isolation is 10 days with the possibility of carrying out an antigen or RT-PCR test to lift isolation on Day 7. Isolation can be lifted if the test result is negative and in the absence of clinical signs of infection for 48 hours. If the test performed on D7 is positive, or in the absence of this test, isolation is for a total of 10 days (no new test to be performed on D10).

description: On March 18, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Higher Education, Research, and Innovation extended the powers of university health services to enable them to carry out health monitoring of isolated students in university residences or the staff of these residences. Higher education establishments, regional health agencies, and local health centers will collaborate to identify isolated students occupying student residences as well as the staff of these residences affected by covid-19, ensure their medical follow-up, and implement the support methods with regard to acts of daily life.

description: 05.11.2020 in France, creation of a centralized national system of information screening, called SI-DEP. The minister of health is the only one in charge of it. "L'assistance publique-Hôpitaux de Paris" handles it on a daily basis. This system aims to centralize the screening results of COVID-19 in order that they're available for the organizations in charge of establishing the persons who have been in contact with COVID-19 cases, so that they may realise sanitary polls in case of group cases in order to break the contamination chains, to give information, to follow and accompany people concerned, and to ease the epidemiological monitoring at both national and local level and the research on the virus as the means to struggle with its spread
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: 05.11.2020 in France, creation of a centralized national system of information screening, called SI-DEP. The minister of health is the only one in charge of it. "L'assistance publique-Hôpitaux de Paris" handles it on a daily basis. This system aims to centralize the screening results of COVID-19 in order that they're available for the organizations in charge of establishing the persons who have been in contact with COVID-19 cases, so that they may realise sanitary polls in case of group cases in order to break the contamination chains, to give information, to follow and accompany people concerned, and to ease the epidemiological monitoring at both national and local level and the research on the virus as the means to struggle with its spread. UPDATE: On January, 31, 2023 it was announced that in accordance with the law of July 30, 2022, the contact tracing system, provided by Health Insurance, ended. Since that date, contact persons no longer receive SMS from Health Insurance. UPDATE: I want to add information that the contact tracing system, provided by Health Insurance, ended on 01.31.2023

description: In France, on the 13th of May 2020, the Health Department (ARS) of the Pays de la Loire announced the implementation of a new contact-tracing system to isolate the virus. They announced that any proven case of COVID-19 will be isolated until they are 'cured', and people who have been in contact with a confirmed case are assessed as ""at risk"", and quarantined for a fortnight as well as subject of a screening test whether they are symptomatic or not.

description: From June 9, 2021, the health pass comes into force and can be integrated into the TousAntiCovid application. Professionals in certain establishments (restaurants, bars, sports halls) must also set up a reminder book, paper or digital via the TousAntiCovid Signal functionality. Includes 3 types of documentation:  - certificate of negative test - a certificate of positive test of at least 15 days and less than 6 months - certificate of vaccination.  The bearer must present their paper pass or QR code when entering an establishment or event that poses a risk of Covid-19 transmission, and will be notified if another visitor subsequently tests positive for Covid-19.   An orange alert is sent if at least one contagious and positive person was in the same place and declared themselves, requiring them to test immediately, to limit contacts and to monitor symptoms. On detection of a cluster, a red alert is sent with instructions to isolate and be tested immediately.  Use of the health pass is required to access certain types of venue, and events over specific sizes depending on location (indoor/outdoor) and type.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: A snapshot of a person’s health at a given point in time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From March 21, 2020, in France, the French High Council for Public Health has proposed a procedure for monitoring contact cases: contact persons at risk, regardless of their vaccination status, should no longer isolate themselves. They should also limit their contacts as far as possible, in particular with people at risk of serious illness, and give preference to teleworking, if applicable.
