description: On March 21 2020, the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the Grand Est region of France announced that on March 18 2020, six Covid-19 patients (in serious condition) from Grand Est had been evacuated to Istres Air Base in Southern France by the French Air Force as part of "Operation Morphée." The six patients had been cared for my Air Force medics during the flight and were subsequently transferred to hospitals in Marseilles and Toulon (as Southern France was less impacted by Covid-19 at the time). This policy was undertaken in accordance with the French national policy of relocation of Covid patients from hospitals in most-affected regions to less-affected regions. UPDATE: On March 21 2020, a further six patients from Mulhouse were evacuated by the French Air Force as part of "Operation Morphée" to hospitals in Bordeaux, Nouvelle-Aquitaine. This policy was undertaken in accordance with the French national policy of relocation of Covid patients from hospitals in most-affected regions to less-affected regions.

description:
On March 23 2020, the Prefect of the Department of Gironde in the Nouvelle-Aquitaine region of France announced that in response to the Covid-19 Pandemic, special accommodation for homeless people was being opened. This included: 
- a conversion of a youth hostel into an accommodation centre for 60 non-infectious homeless individuals 
- the opening of a special centre for isolation of homeless people infected with Covid-19 (capacity of 12) 
- an additional 166 places for accommodation of homeless people during winter (alongside the regular 1587 places provided throughout the year)
And end date to this program was not given.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: The region of Pays de la Loire is encouraging individuals in possession of an excess amount of masks are to hand them in to the nearest pharmacy if the individual has less than 500 masks, to call a government hotline or email a specific email address if they have more than 500 masks, or contact the ministry of health if they have more than 200,000 masks. If the masks have not expired, the individual may receive a receipt of compensation. The prefecture makes this policy on the basis that 'masks are a precious resource', with the intention to distribute these masks to surgeons and other healthcare workers.

description: On March 24 2020, the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the Grand Est region of France announced that as part of regional efforts to procure surgical masks, local companies had capable of mask production had been identified and ordered to redirct their production towards masks. As of March 24 2020, 14 enterprises had been identified in Vosges, Aube, Moselle, Bas-Rhin and Haut-Rhin. 3 factories had already commenced mask production and 11 more were awaiting approval. Furthermore, a "Mask Cell" had been activated by the ARS and the Regional Council of Grand Est to distribute masks as efficiently as possible to those who needed them.

description: On the 1 April 2020, the Regional Health Agency of the Grand Est region of France announced the decision to create specific accommodation for Covid patients (without serious symptoms) who could not isolate at home due to extenuating factors (for example: co-morbidity risks, no possibility of isolation) and homeless people. Appropriate accommodation was to be identified by the Prefects of Departments, and the Regional Health Agency was to provide provide support if necessary. Several of these centres were also operated by NGOs - such as the Red Cross.

description: From April 2, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has announced that in the event that it is impossible to supply pharmaceutical medicines for human use to patients, medicinal products for veterinary use with a similar therapeutic ail, of the same active substance, the same strength and the same route of administration, can be prescribed, prepared, dispensed and administered in a hospital environment. The list of these drugs and their active ingredients and their conditions of preparation and use are set by the National Agency for the Safety of Medicines and health products and published on its website.

description: On the week of the 1 April 2020, 5 million masks commandered by the Grand Est region of France and funded by the European Union arrived in Grand Est. Of the 5 million masks, 2 million were sent to services such as aged care and disability care, and 3 million were sent to healthcare workers. UPDATE: On the 3 April 2020, the French military delivered over 92,000 masks of the 5 million masks commandered by the Grand Est region to the Department of Meuse. These masks were distributed to healthcare workers, aged care workers, and childcare workers.

description: On March 25 2020, the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the Grand Est region of France announced that a medical train staffed by a team from Grand Est would start operating that day. The train was made avaiable from the French national railway company, SNCF, and could transport 4 patients per carriage. A medical team consisting of an ICU doctor, one intern, one anaesthetic nurse and three generalist nurses would work onboard the train. This policy was undertaken in accordance with the French national policy of relocation of Covid patients from hospitals in most-affected regions to less-affected regions. UPDATE: On April 3 2020, a medical train was used to evacuate 24 patients from hospitals in the Grand Est region of France (in Strasbourg, Colmar, Saverne, Sélestat and Haguenau) to the Nouvelle-Aquitaine region of France. This was the final medical evacuation by train of patients from Grand Est to other regions on France. This policy was undertaken in accordance with the French national policy of relocation of Covid patients from hospitals in most-affected regions to less-affected regions.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 4, 2020, France announced additional provisions and principles of action in order to support people with disabilities, including to reinforce setups and real-time monitoring of the development of the epidemic in the disability sector, strengthen preventive measures in establishments supporting people with disabilities, not to leave establishments and services alone to deal with covid-19 cases, to anticipate and organize treatment at the hospital when necessary, to strengthen the continuity of medico-social support during the duration of the epidemic, and to take the greatest care in identifying the respite needs of carers exposed to a risk of physical and mental exhaustion, as well as support needs of isolated people.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: 04.28.2020 in France, the French Prime Minister has stated that the “brigades” of people will be created who are responsible to trace contacts of people who test positive for Covid-19 after confinement ends, to help contain further spread of the virus. "Prime minister Edouard Philippe made the announcement as part of his speech on Tuesday April 28. He said: “[We want to] protect, test, isolate. In each department, we will have brigades whose job it is to compile a list of contacts, and to call them, to invite them to be tested, telling them where to go for a test, and then to check that these tests have indeed been done.”
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: On June 1st, 2020, French secretary of economy, Agnès Pannier-Runacher, announced that the Direction générale de la concurrence, de la consommation et de la répression des fraudes (DGCCRF) is going to make surveys about masks to guarantee access to good quality masks at reasonable prices, and make sure claims about them are true. French government decided to regulate the price of masks for use unique type of surgery and to implement a monitoring of the prices of masks. The DGCCRF will monitor compliance with regulated prices and monitor the other prices. The maximum price per mask will be 0.95 cents of euro, after taxes.

description: As of January 8, as part of the coronavirus crisis, the French government has set up a toll-free information number at: "0 800 130,000". This free service is available every day, from 9 a.m. to 7 p.m. It provides for the possibility of being put in touch with a psychological support system. In order to better manage mental health during this period, Public Health France carried out an inventory of reference sites and remote helplines. The Psycom has also produced a page of useful resources for mental health and a list of psychological support lines.

description: 02.26.2020 in France, the Ministry for Solidarity and Health has stated that "Extra resources have been allocated for testing for potential cases of coronavirus and the testing capacity has been multiplied by three. Health minister Olivier Véran said: "I have called the head of the University Hospital Institute of Infectious Diseases in Marseille, it is able to perform 1,000 tests per day in the area of Marseille alone. In the hospitals of Paris we are at 400 tests per day. We are going to be able to amplify the screening to be able to answer all the requests at that scale across France."
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: On March 19 2020, the Regional Health Agency of the Grand Est region of France announced that testing for Covid-19 was reserved for (symptomatic) vulnerable people, hospitalised people and healthcare professionals only, to avoid saturation of the testing system.

description: 03.28.2020 in France, the French National Government has announced that tests are currently reserved for priority groups which are symptomatic health professionals, symptomatic elderly people, people with severe breathing difficulties or comorbidities, and people hospitalized. In accordance with the recommendations of the WHO which now encourages mass testing of the population and in view of the evolution of the epidemic, the testing strategy in France will evolve in the coming months
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: 03.28.2020 in France, the French National Government has announced that for patients diagnosed in hospital or with signs of severity, the tests will be performed in hospitals. For other patients meeting the screening criteria, it is possible to be tested in laboratories in town, after contact with the attending physician and medical prescription. The samples will be taken at home. In no case should you go directly to the biological laboratories, but call them beforehand, and only if you have a medical prescription, because there is a great risk of infecting other patients, especially the most fragile
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of March 28, 2020 in France, the French National Government has announced that 12,000 PCR tests are performed each day, and by the end of April 50,000 conventional tests will be performed. In parallel, rapid tests are now available and France has ordered 5 million. The rapid test capacity will be increased to 30,000 per day in April 60,000 in May to reach 100,000 rapid tests in June.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: On the 27 April 2020, the Department of Meuse, located in the Grand Est region of France, announced an intensive testing program. Using the RT-PCR nasal swab testing method, the program targeted accommodation housing vulnerable people. The testing took place in: aged-care residences, residencies for people with disabilities, autonomous residences, crisis accommodation, and medical-social accommodation facilities. Facilities with large numbers of confirmed Covid-19 cases were given first priority, followed by facilities with at least one confirmed or suspected case, followed by facilities with no current confirmed cases.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries

description: France will implement a new doctrine on COVID-19 testing on May 11, 2020, with the aim of testing everyone who has come into contact with people who are infected, Prime Minister Edouard Philippe told parliament. He said the government had set itself the goal of carrying out at least 700,000 tests per week starting from May 11, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: From the 11 May 2020, the Department of Haut-Rhin, located in the Grand Est region of France, implimented a new policy of testing-tracing-isolation. People suspected to have Covid-19 were tested at 39 designated testing sites. If they tested positive, efforts were made to trace their recent close contacts. Both the recent close contacts and persons who tested positive were then instructed to self-isolate.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries
enforcer: Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On the 16 May 2020, the Department of Meuse in the Grand Est region of France announced a new system of health testing and tracing. If residents displayed symptoms of Covid-19, they were instructed to self-isolate and contact a doctor, who would prescribe a RT-PCR type test for them. Individuals then had to visit the nearest testing facility (where they could complete necessary paperwork, or could complete it before) and await 24 hours for their result. If the test was positive, residents had to contact the Caisse Primaire d’Assurance Maladie (CPAM) of Meuse, which would perform contact tracing. 31 testing facilities were to be set up in Meuse, with one drive-through testing facility opening on the 18 May.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries
enforcer: Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On September 28 2020, the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the Nouvelle-Aquitaine region of France, in conjunction with the Mayor of Floiriac, the University Hospital of Bordeaux and the Bordeaux Métropole, announced a new Covid testing operation for prioritised populations only. 

Symptomatic people, health workers, at-home carers, and health students were eligible to be tested, and had to prevent either a student card, professional membership card (for health workers), proof of health insurance, proof of employment as an at-home carer, or a medical certificate order to be eligible for the testing. 

Testing was available Monday to Friday from September 28 2020 to October 30 2020. Two seperate designated testing centres in Bordeaux were used throughout the campaign.

description:
11.17.2020 in France, the Scientific Council notes that antigen tests for diagnostic purposes are now available, that their sensitivity is better known and that they have 2 major advantages: a response in less than 30 minutes as well as raising citizens' awareness of the diagnosis of COVID-19 that can facilitate isolation.

"In this short note, the Scientific Council draws two scenarios around an optimization of screening:

A "Mass Testing" screening strategy at the end of confinement;
A screening strategy more targeted at at-risk populations during the containment phase and at its exit."

description: Starting from March 1, there are new measures in France after the health situation in Moselle. The derogation from the obligation to present a PCR test of fewer than 72 hours on entry into the national territory will be limited only to professional activities. Border crossers who travel for reasons other than professional reasons must present a negative PCR test at the border. Nevertheless, the strategy of identification of contact cases and isolation has also been strengthened (with an isolation obligation increased from 7 to 10 days, a measure then extended to the entire national territory).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: 04.02.2021, The Ministry of Solidarity and Health has announced that in case if a child over 12 years old is unvaccinated and has a positive case, the following procedure should be implemented: isolation for a period of 10 days after the date of the onset of signs or the date of collection of the positive test (10 full days). Lifting of isolation is possible on Day 7 with a negative antigen or RT-PCR test result (and in the absence of clinical signs of infection for 48 hours). If the test carried out on D7 is positive or if this test is not carried out, isolation is for a total of 10 days (no new test to be carried out on D10).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Lateral flow tests are available in French pharmacies from April 12, 2021, to anyone aged over 15, with the following provisions in force:  - For sale in pharmacies (not yet in supermarkets; online sales are banned) - Only to be used by people aged 15 and over without symptoms - Priced at €6 each maximum, reducing to €5.20 from May 15 - Not reimbursed except in the case of some vulnerable people or carers of vulnerable people - Any positive result must immediately be confirmed with a RT-PCR test - Anyone with a positive result must immediately self-isolate and inform their recent contacts. RT-PCR tests remain generally available to all, whether symptomatic or asymptomatic, with cost fully covered by health insurance per Government guidelines.

description: On 12 March, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health of France announced that to curb the spread of the virus, the simplest and most effective measure is to apply and enforce all barrier gestures immediately and everywhere on the territory. description: France, Hauts-de-France, March 18th, 2020. The government is providing increased access to soap and water in areas with large migrant populations. In the Calais district, the government has installed soap dispensers near water sources, and is also distributing 150 to 200 jugs of water each day. In the commune of Grande-Synthe, a water tank and a drum of liquid soap were installed at the end of February 2020 near private buildings known to be occupied by migrants. The sites, which are operational 7 days a week, are supervised to ensure social distancing during the hand-washing process.

transportation as well as personnel from the loading or unloading sites. If not provided with a water point, these places are provided with hydro-alcoholic gel.

description:
From March 27, 2020 in France until June 22, 2020, the Minister of Territorial Cohesion and Relations with Local Authorities announced the following temporary exemptions for funeral operators from various funeral law provision in light of covid-19: 
- the transport of the body of a deceased person before and after being put in the coffin can be carried out without prior declaration (declaration must be sent to the mayor no later than one month after the end of this policy)
- The deadlines for burial or cremation may be waived without the prior consent of the prefect to the extent strictly necessary (declaration must be sent to the prefect specifying the delay period implemented no later than 15 days after the burial or cremation)
- the authorization to close the coffin can be transmitted by the registrar to the funeral operator in a dematerialized manner
- The transport of bodies before and after being put in the coffin can be provided by vehicles, acquired or rented by authorized funeral operators."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On the 27 March 2020, the French Department of the Economy, Finances and Revival annouced new hygeine guidelines regarding postal delivery procedures. Warehouses were instructed to maximise the size of deliveries in order to prevent multiple deliveries, and delivery personnel were instructed to knock or phone occupants and leave the delivery on the doorstep. People receiving postal deliveries were instructed to wait before opening the door to allow the delivery personnel to stand back. One metre of distance was ordered to be maintained at all times, and at all stages of the process (packing, sorting and delivery) hygeine measures such as hand-washing were to be maintained. This policy was aimed at postal workers, packing and warehouse workers, and people who recieve postal deliveries.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 31 May 2020, the French national government announces that: I. - Any operator of public or private collective road passenger transport by coach or bus, or guided or rail transport, shall inform passengers of the hygiene measures [...], by means of audible announcements and by means of a display in the areas accessible to the public and assigned to public passenger transport and onboard each vehicle or rolling stock.
II. - The manager of the spaces assigned to public passenger transport shall provide access to a water and soap point or hydro-alcoholic gel for passengers.
III. - In the vehicles mentioned in I of article 21 (private public transport services for persons; private or public transport services using vehicles with fewer than nine seats, excluding the driver; vehicles used for carpooling; social transport services): 
1° A notice reminding the passengers of the hygiene measures [...] is put up inside the vehicle ;
2° For vehicles with two or more rows of rear seats, hydro-alcoholic gel is made available to passengers
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 14, 2020, Prime Minister Édouard Philippe tells citizens not to travel between towns unless essential. He further asks them to work from home and only go outside to buy essential supplies, to take light exercise and to vote in the local elections. Public transport will remain open but he encourages cresidents to limit their usage. UPDATE: On May 7, 2020, in France, the Prime Minister, the Minister of Interior, the Minister of Health, the Minister of Transport, the Minister of the National Education and the Minister of the Economy and Finance, the Minister of Labour presented the roadmap of the release of lockdown in France. This also removes the restrictions on movement. The nationwide lockdown would end in all departments (both red and green) except Mayotte on May 11 2020. Vulnerable populations (such as elderly people and those with chronic illnesses) were released from lockdown but Prime Minister Phillipe advised these populations 'act with caution.' This announcement ended the nationwide lockdown announced on March 23 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From May 11, 2020 in France, any movement of a person leading them both to leave a perimeter defined by a radius of 100 kilometers from their place of residence and to leave the department in which the latter is located is prohibited except travel for the following reasons:
(1) Travel for work that cannot be postponed. 
(2) Travel to school or other educational establishments by a student or thier parent or carer and necessary trips to get to school exams or competitions.
(3) Travel for medical appointements that cannot be provided remotely or closer to home;
(4) Travel for urgent family reasons, and for the assistance of vulnerable people, people with disabilities and for childcare;
(5) Travel to report to law enforcement
(6) Travel to report to administrative court or judicial authority
(7) Travel at the request of the administrative authority
The department prefect is allowed to adopt more restrictive travel conditions within a department when local circumstances so require. People traveling under an exeption must bring with them, during their travels, a declaration indicating the reason for the trip accompanied, documents justifying this reason, and proof of place of residence. UPDATE: Starting June 2, 2020 in France, the border restriction for trips longer than 100 km from the home is lifted.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On March 14th 2020 the RATP (Régie Autonome des Transports Parisiens) announced that, as of March 15th, transit lines throughout Paris and the Île-de-France region of France will run less often due to a shortage of staff. This will reduce travel within the region and the reason for this change is the need for parents to stay home because of school closures related to COVID-19. UPDATE: On June 1st 2020 the national government of France announced that RATP (Régie Autonome des Transports Parisiens) traffic will be increased throughout Paris and the Île-de-France region as of June 2nd 2020. Metro traffic will be back to 100% and all traffic in general will resume to 90% of its usual amount.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: From May 11, 2020 in France, President Macron and the Minister of Solidarity and Health have restricted internal travel without a permission slip to within a 100km radius from a person's place of residence. The department prefect is allowed to adopt more restrictive travel conditions within a department when local circumstances so require. UPDATE: On May 28, 2020 in France, the Prime Minister announced that starting June 2, 2020, the internal border restriction on trips longer than 100 km from the home will be lifted.

description:
"Since June 22, 2020, are prohibited, unless they are based on an overriding personal or family reason, an emergency health reason or a professional reason that cannot be postponed, flights between, of on the one hand, Guyana, Mayotte, French Polynesia, New Caledonia or Wallis and Futuna and, on the other hand, any point in the territory of the Republic.

For flights from or to French Polynesia and New Caledonia, depending on local circumstances, the State representative is empowered to complete the list of reasons that justify the trips.

Anyone wishing to benefit from one of these derogatory grounds must present, when boarding, the document (s) justifying this, as well as a declaration of honor for this reason"

description:
"Starting July 10, 2020, the prefect of a department can, for certain hours, limit the spaces and vehicles of public transport to individuals with specific motives. 
These motives include:
(1) travel from and to work or for other professional reasons
(2) travel from and to school, including accompanying others 
(3) travel for health consultations
(4) travel for compelling family reasons, for the assistance of vulnerable people, for respite and support for disabled people and for childcare
(5) travel to report to the policy/a judicial authority
(6) travel to court
(7) travel related to a change of residence/acquisition of rental estate that cannot be deferred"

description:
From March 19, 2020 until March 31, 2020 in France, in accordance with the national lockdown, movement outside of the home is prohibited except for the following reasons: 
(1) Journeys between home and work that cannot be postponed.
(2) Travel to purchase basic necessities such as groceries.
(3) Travel for health reasons
(4) Travel for compelling family reasons, for the assistance of vulnerable people or for childcare.
(5) Short trips, close to home, related to the individual physical activity (exclusion team sports) and the needs of pets. 
(6) Travel to report to law enforcement.
(7) Travel to report to administrative or judicial authorities.
(8) Travel at the request of the administrative authority.
Local government officials may further restrict movement if local conditions require. People traveling outside of the home for these exceptions must bring documentation justifying their movements fall within the scope of these exceptions. Violation of limits on moving outside one's home, failure to bring documentation justifying an authorized trip, and violation of additional local restrictions where applicable will be punished with a fine of 135 euros on a first offense and 375 euros on the second offense.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On May 7 2020, the French government announced that lockdown conditions would remain in place in the Department of Mayotte until a decision was made on May 14 2020 (the rest of France would be progressively released from lockdown after May 11 2020). 
These conditions were: movement outside of the home is prohibited except for the following reasons:
  (1) Journeys between home and work that cannot be postponed.
  (2) Travel to purchase basic necessities such as groceries.
  (3) Travel for medical appointments that cannot be completed through video meetings
  (4) Travel for compelling family reasons, for the assistance of vulnerable people and for childcare;
  (5) Short trips, close to home, related to the individual physical activity (excluding team sports) and the needs of pets. These trips are limited to one hour per day, within a maximum radius of one kilometer around the home, and prohibit any proximity to other people except people from the same home.
(6) Travel to report to law enforcement.
(7) Travel to report to administrative or judicial authority
(8) Travel at the request of the administrative authority.
People travelling outside of the home for these exceptions must bring documentation justifying their movements fall within the scope of these exceptions. Violations of lockdown measures are punishable by fines or imprisonment.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

UPDATE: On May 7, 2020, in France, the Prime Minister, the Minister of Interior, the Minister of Health, the Minister of Transport, the Minister of the National Education and the Minister of the Economy and Finance, the Minister of Labour presented the roadmap of the release of lockdown in France. The nationwide lockdown would end in all departments (both red and green) except Mayotte on May 11 2020, but red departments would have stronger restrictions on schools and government services/businesses than green departments. Vulnerable populations (such as elderly people and those with chronic illnesses) were released from lockdown but Prime Minister Phillipe advised these populations 'act with caution.' This announcement ended the nationwide lockdown announced on March 23 2020.

description:
In France, from October 30, 2020 and for a duration of at least four weeks (with reassessment every two weeks) a national lockdown is declared. All travel by persons outside their place of residence is prohibited except for the following reasons : 
1. Travel to or from:
(a) The place where a person is engaged in or seeking employment, and business trips that cannot be postponed
b) establishments or services for the reception of minors, education or training for adults mentioned in articles 32 to 35 of this decree
c) The place where an examination or a competition is organized;
2. Travel to make purchases of supplies necessary for the professional activity, purchases of basic necessities, withdrawals of orders and home deliveries
3. Travel for consultations, examinations and treatments that cannot be provided at a distance and for the purchase of medication
4. Travel for compelling family reasons, for assistance to vulnerable and precarious people, for childcare, as well as for removals
5. Travel for disabled people and their companions
6. Short trips, within the limit of one hour per day and within a maximum radius of one kilometer around the home, related either to the individual physical activity of the persons, excluding any collective sports practice and any proximity with other persons, or to the walk with the only persons grouped in the same home, or to the needs of pets
7. Travel to respond to a judicial or administrative summons or to go to a public
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

1. Travel to or from:
(a) The place where a person is engaged in or seeking employment, and business trips that cannot be postponed
b) establishments or services for the reception of minors, education or training for adults mentioned in articles 32 to 35 of this decree
c) The place where an examination or a competition is organized;

4. Travel for compelling family reasons, for assistance to vulnerable and precarious people, for childcare, as well as for removals

Short trips, within the limit of one hour per day and within a maximum radius of one kilometer around the home, related either to the individual physical activity of the persons, excluding any collective sports practice and any proximity with other persons, or to the walk with the only persons grouped in the same home, or to the needs of pets
7. Travel to respond to a judicial or administrative summons or to go to a public UPDATE: On November 26 2020, the French government announced a loosening of lockdown restrictions from November 28 2020. 
The new rules were: People were now allowed to exercise for up to three hours a day (including travel time) within a 20km radius of their homes. Individual hunting, fishing and swimming was also allowed. Property visits from letting agents could resume. Exemption certificates for movement were to remain. 
President Macron also announced that the nationwide lockdown wound end on December 15 2020, and be replaced with a curfew.

description:
On March 18 2021, French Prime Minister Jean Castex announced a full lockdown in sixteen departments of France, including the entire regions of Île-de-France and Hauts-de-France, as well as the departments of Eure (Normandy), Seine-Maritime (Normandy) and Alpes-Maritimes (Provence-Alpes-Côte-d'Azur) from midnight March 19 2021. This lockdown was slated to last for four weeks. 

The full list of accepted reasons for going out are:
- Physical exercise, walking, walking the dog (within 10 km of your home, no time limit)
- Shopping for basic necessities, or to pick up ordered goods
- Accompanying children to school or out-of-school activities
- Visiting a cultural establishment (libraries and media libraries) or a place of worship
- Attending to administrative or legal formalities

Permitted reasons for travelling outside your department are: 
-For work, education and training, general interest missions
- Health reasons (consultations and care/treatment)
- Compelling family reasons, to help vulnerable or needy persons, or for childcare
- Transporting people with disabilities and their carers
- Judicial or administrative summons
- Moving home
- Transit travel to stations and airports 

An exemption certificate was required for all trips out of home.

description:
On March 18 2021, French Prime Minister Jean Castex announced a full lockdown in sixteen departments of France, including the entire regions of Île-de-France and Hauts-de-France, as well as the departments of Eure (Normandy), Seine-Maritime (Normandy) and Alpes-Maritimes (Provence-Alpes-Côte-d'Azur) from midnight March 19 2021. This lockdown was slated to last for four weeks. 

The full list of accepted reasons for going out are:
- Physical exercise, walking, walking the dog (within 10 km of your home, no time limit)
- Shopping for basic necessities, or to pick up ordered goods
- Accompanying children to school or out-of-school activities
- Visiting a cultural establishment (libraries and media libraries) or a place of worship
- Attending to administrative or legal formalities

Permitted reasons for travelling outside your department are: 
-For work, education and training, general interest missions
- Health reasons (consultations and care/treatment)
- Compelling family reasons, to help vulnerable or needy persons, or for childcare
- Transporting people with disabilities and their carers
- Judicial or administrative summons
- Moving home
- Transit travel to stations and airports 

An exemption certificate was required for all trips out of home. UPDATE: On March 26 2021, the French government announced that a further three departments Rhône (Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes), Aube (Grand Est) and Nièvre (Bourgogne-Franche-Comté) would be placed into full lockdown for four weeks from March 27 2021. This ended the previous targeted lockdown.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
On March 31 2021, the French President Emmanuel Macron announced a nationwide lockdown in all French departments from April 3 2021 for four weeks. 

The full list of accepted reasons for going out are (no attestation form needed) were:
-Physical exercise, walking, walking the dog (within 10 km of your home)
-Shopping for basic necessities, or to pick up ordered goods
-Accompanying children to school or out-of-school activities
-Visiting a cultural establishment (libraries and media libraries) or a place of worship
-Attending to administrative or legal formalities

Permitted reasons for travelling outside your department with an attestation are: 
-For work, education and training, general interest missions
-Health reasons (consultations and care/treatment)
-Compelling family reasons, to help vulnerable or needy persons, or for childcare
-Transporting people with disabilities and their carers
-Judicial or administrative summons
-Moving home
-Transit travel to stations and airports 

Those living close to the border of their department are allowed to travel up to 30km from their home for the above reasons. Everyone who can should work from home, although there is still an exemption for one day a week of work in the workplace for people who feel their mental health is being affected by 100 percent home-working. Violations were punishable by fine and imprisonment.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

On March 31 2021, the French President Emmanuel Macron announced a nationwide lockdown in all French departments from April 3 2021 for four weeks. 

The full list of accepted reasons for going out are (no attestation form needed) were:
-Physical exercise, walking, walking the dog (within 10 km of your home)
-Shopping for basic necessities, or to pick up ordered goods
-Accompanying children to school or out-of-school activities

description: On July 30 2021, There is no recommendation to stay at home within metropolitan France. In Guadaloupe,  a curfew is in place between 21:00 and 5:00 from 30 July. In Martinique, a lockdown is in place from 19:00 to 5:00. From 5:00 to 19:00, only travel within a radius of 10km is allowed from a person's home, with exceptions for travel to work. Teleworking is recommended, whenever possible. Discotheques are closed. Restuarants are only allowed to serve customers at outdoor tables, or provide take-away services. Restuarants and bars located in enclosed shopping cetners over 5000m2 are not allowed to open, unless only accessible from a public road.      In La Reunion from July 31, a lockdown will be enforced from from 18:00 to 5:00. From 5:00 to 18:00, only travel within a radius of 10km on weekdays and 5km on weekends from a person's home will be allowed, beyond which proof of compelling reason for travel will be required.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: France. In late February 2020, the City of Lyon formed a strategic and operational supervisory committee for managing the Covid-19 crisis. This committee is operational 7 days a week under the authority of the Mayor of Lyon. On March 17th, the city announced that the committee's functions range from planning for the elections that will take place in March and June, to organizing services for individuals in need due to the pandemic. On May 11th, 2020, the City of Lyon announced that the strategic and operational supervisory committee will begin working on Lyon's reopening plan.

description: On March 22, 2020 in Switzerland the three cantons of Basel-City, Basel-Landschaft and Jura announced that the French Departement Haut-Rhin sent an urgent request for support to the three cantons on March 20. In consultation with the federal authorities, the three governments have agreed that ICU patients from France can be transferred to the cantonal hospitals. Further Swiss cantons ( Aargau, Bern, Fribourg, Geneva, Lucerne, Neuchâtel, Saint Gallen, Schaffhausen, Thurgau, Vaud, Valais, Zurich ) offered help and took ICU patients from French regions Grand-Est and Franche-Comté.

description: On 6 September, France added 7 new departments to its list of COVID-19 "red zones" as the country experiences resurgence of cases of the virus. New additions include: Corse-du-Sud, Haute-Corse, Côte-d'Or, Nord, Bas-Rhin, Seine-Maritime, and the Réunion Island. description: The French "Comité de contrôle et de liaison Covid-19 "(CCL-COVID) is established by Law No. 2020-546 of 11 May 2020. It is responsible for involving civil society and Parliament in operations to combat the spread of the epidemic by monitoring contacts and in the deployment of information systems provided for this purpose. This committee is responsible to evaluate the real contribution of digital tools to their action and to verify throughout these operations the respect of the guarantees surrounding medical secrecy and the protection of personal data. The Covid-19 Control and Liaison Committee are placed under the Ministry of Solidarity and Health. Its secretariat is provided by the Directorate-General for Health (Steering and Support Policy Service) with the support of the secretariat of the National Health Conference.

description: On March 23, 2020, the city of Lyon, in Auvergne-Rhône-Alps, France launched a platform called "Neighbors Together Lyon" to help connect people who need help with those who can provide it. Types of assistance provided through this platform will include "helping those with limited access to transportation, assisting caretakers, printing travel attestations to those without access to a printer, buying groceries, helping with homework, walking domestic pets, talking with and combatting the isolation of people living alone." Individuals using this platform are asked to abide by current health measures when providing/receiving assistance.

description: On January 14, 2020, the French Health Ministry activated the mailing list, DGS-Urgent. DGS-Urgent provides health professionals with automatic updates on health emergencies via MSSanté (an electronic messaging tool for healthcare workers). The updates can be found on the Health Ministry's website or will be sent directly to health professionals who subscribe. DGS-Urgent provides up-to-date information on the number of COVID-19 cases, the distribution of personal protective equipment, COVID prevention, vaccination, testing, and other relevant topics.

description: The news broadcaster France 24 published an article about masks and which one is better against the background of recent events. According to them, of the two main types of face masks on the market - N95 respirators, which fit snugly to the face and include a filtration system, and surgical face masks, which are usually worn by hospital workers - it is the latter that provides the best protection against the virus. Respirators are designed to protect the user because they want to keep pollutants out,” it says. “[Surgical masks] are actually in the healthcare industry designed to protect patients."
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 20, 2020, the French Health Ministry published a brochure for hospitals and health professionals on the current COVID situation. The document included information about the activation of MARS (Rapid Health Alerts), which can send out health alerts to different sectors of the health industry seven days a week. The alerts will be distributed rapidly and pertain to current guidelines. The document also calls for hospitals and other health agencies to host training for staff who will be in contact with COVID patients. Emergency care teaching centers, including SAMU (Urgent Medical Aid Service) and SMIT (Office of Infectious and Tropical Diseases) will help with this training. Staff will be taught how to effectively use personal protective equipment, how COVID is transmitted, how government health agencies will function, how cases are classified, and confidentiality for individuals exposed to COVID. The French Ministry of Health is currently the only group that can announce the number of confirmed cases and deaths.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Beginning on March 16, 2020, the French government sent many citizens a text alert to remind them of restrictions that were currently in place to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The message reminded people that they were prohibited from leaving their homes unless they had a attestation pass and essential reason to leave. They included a link to the French government's coronavirus webpage, where people could find more information. The messages were sent to approximately 80 million people over the period of several days.

description: On March 27, 2020, the French Public Health Agency published guidelines on hand-washing in the form of a printable graphic. Anyone can download the graphic from the government's website. Pictures demonstrate the proper technique for washing one's hands. Using soap and water, people should scrub all over their hands, including their fingernails. If water and soap are unavailable, use hand sanitizer. The poster also provides the link to the government's coronavirus information page and a toll free number that people can call for more information.

description: On June 2, 2020, the French national government launched StopCovid. StopCovid is an app launched to alert people who are in contact with someone who tests positive for COVID-19. description: On 27 July 2020, the Ministry of Health and Prevention of France announced information and recommendations in order to increase the awareness of the public. To better follow the epidemic, people can find the data of the 4 COVID-19 monitoring indicators on the government dashboard: https://dashboard.covid19.data.gouv.fr/suivi-indicateurs?location=FRA. You will find there the information relating to the weekly incidence rate, the R - number of effective reproduction, the occupancy rate of the beds in intensive care, and the positivity rate of the RT-PCR virological tests. The data are available at the national level via the graphs and at the departmental level via the maps. They were updated on a weekly basis.

description: On September 25, 2020, the French national government shared printable posters with guidelines about wearing masks in order to protect oneself from new COVID-19 variants. Anyone can download the posters. These posters contained the following information: the government recommends wearing masks when maintaining a distance of 6 feet is not possible. Homemade masks should no longer be worn because they do not provide enough filtration. Healthcare professionals should wear FFP2 masks (without valves) or surgical masks, and citizens should wear cloth masks. People with COVID and hospital visitors should wear surgical masks. Masks must cover the chin, nose, and mouth and be fitted tightly to the face to be effective. People should wash their hands before putting on their masks and should not touch the mask once securing it to their faces.

description: From October 7 2020, the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the Grand Est region of France launched a campaign aimed at students, encouraging them to the correct preventative behaviours ("barrier gestures") of Covid-19 (such as hand-washing, hygeine etc), even when they were asymptomatic. The campaign focused on encouraging a "controlled" social life. Four key settings for behaviour change were targeted the campaign - weekends with families, nights out with friends, sharing a car, and sharing study spaces at universities. Posters were available to download and print, information was provided on the ARS website, and were into shareable photos/GIFs for Facebook, Instagram and Snapchat.

description: On October 29, 2020, the Directorate of Legal and Administrative Information published a webpage explaining the current state of emergency in France. The webpage explains that a state of medical emergency can be declared by the law and provides the dates that the state of emergency was in effect. It also explains that the state of emergency temporarily limits the freedoms to travel and meet and allows the govenment to temporarily control prices. It highlights punishments of violating government guidelines (up to 6 months imprisonment and a 10,000 euro fine). The webpage includes a link to a Youtube video that explains why the state of emergency was declared and what it entails.

description: On November 3 2020, the French national government announced the launch of a special number of information on emergency measures for companies struggling due to the COVID-19 Pandemic: 0806 000 245 (non-premium rate call, price of a local call) effective from November 2nd, 2020 at 9 am. Help is available from 9 am to 12 pm and 1 pm to 4 pm Monday to Friday. Companies can call for information about their eligibility for aid or with other questions about the measures being taken to help businesses. The number is meant to be used in conjunction with the existing government website to aid businesses with responding to COVID (https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises).

description: On September 21, 2021, the French Ministry of Health published a website, responding to frequently asked questions about receiving booster doses of the COVID-19 vaccines. The site addresses who is eligible, why people should receive a booster, where boosters are being offered, and how many people have received boosters. The site also explains how vaccine passports will be updated to reflect the booster dose and reports how many people have currently received their booster shots. Currently, only people in higher risk categories (ex. those over 65, people with comorbidities, those who are immunocompromised). People who received the Janssen vaccine at least four weeks previously are eligible to receive a booster. The website contains a graphic that anyone can download. It shows eligibility by age and conditions and includes the link to the Health Ministry's website, where people can find more information.

description: Following national deconfinement on 11 May 2020, the prefect of the Haut-Rhin department of France made a press release detailing a health organization system based on tracing, screening and isolating known cases. Haut-Rhin has established a policy where people who have tested positive and those who have been in contact with them need to isolate. The priority is for people to isolate in their homes, however people who are not able or willing can isolate in two hotels in Colmar and Mulhouse. A territorial support unit has been set up by the prefecture to assist patients who will be isolated.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: From May 11, 2020, any travelers who enter France from outside the EU’s open-border Schengen area – whether citizens or foreigners – will face a mandatory two-week quarantine upon arrival. Those entering from EU countries or the United Kingdom will be exempt, although Health Minister Olivier Véran has suggested that France reserves the right to impose specific restrictions “if the epidemic situation were to get out of control in one of the Schengen countries”.

UPDATE: From May 11, 2020, any travelers who enter France from outside the EU’s open-border Schengen area – whether citizens or foreigners – will face a mandatory two-week quarantine upon arrival. Those entering from EU countries or the United Kingdom will be exempt.

description: From 25 May 2020 until June 15, 2020, the French Government is putting in place a voluntary 14-day quarantine measure for travelers arriving from countries outside the European area (includes all countries of the world except EU members, Andorra, Iceland, Lichtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland, Vatican City). There is an exception to this measure: for travelers arriving from European countries whose authorities have decided, in an uncoordinated fashion, to apply 14-day quarantine measures to travelers entering their territory from European countries, a voluntary 14-day quarantine period will be reciprocally requested. Therefore, travelers from UK and Spain are subject to a voluntary quarantine regardless of their nationality due to their country's policies.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

Permitted arrivals from other countries must meet the same condition or take a test on arrival. Permitted travelers from all other locations are able to present a negative COVID-19 test taken within the previous 72 hours or take a test on arrival; otherwise, they are required to self-isolate for 7 days.

description:
From Monday, January 18 2021, all travelers who wish to come to France, from a country outside the European Union will have to carry out a test before leaving. In addition, the persons concerned will have to undertake on their honor to isolate themselves for 7 days once they arrive in France, then redo a second PCR test at the end.
For the few countries where it is not possible to carry out a test on-site, the person will be tested on arrival in France and will be forced to isolate themselves for 7 days in an establishment designated by the State.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
France announced that from December 9, 2020, permitted travelers arriving from Algeria, Bahrain, China, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ecuador, Iraq, Iran, Israel, Lebanon, Morocco, Panama, South Africa, Russia, Turkey, Ukraine, United Arab Emirates, the US, and Zimbabwe must present proof of having tested negative for COVID-19 within 72 hours prior to boarding. Permitted arrivals from other countries must meet the same condition or take a test on arrival. Permitted travelers from all other locations are able to present a negative COVID-19 test taken within the previous 72 hours or take a test on arrival; otherwise, they are required to self-isolate for 7 days. UPDATE: "From Monday, January 18 2021, all travelers who wish to come to France, from a country outside the European Union will have to carry out a test before leaving. In addition, the persons concerned will have to undertake on their honor to isolate themselves for 7 days once they arrive in France, then redo a second PCR test at the end.
For the few countries where it is not possible to carry out a test on-site, the person will be tested on arrival in France and will be forced to isolate themselves for 7 days in an establishment designated by the State."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of 24 January, France already requires travelers from outside the EU to produce proof of a negative PCR COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours prior to departure. However, travelers from outside the EU must also self-isolate for seven days on arrival, with a second test being required at the end of the isolation period. Travelers unable to take a test in the country of departure may do so on arrival but must submit to seven days of isolation at a government-designated facility.

description: 12.16.2020 in France, faced with the extremely rapid spread of the Omicron variant in the United Kingdom, the French Government is strengthening the requirement for tests for travel to and from the United Kingdom. Thus, as of this Saturday (12.18.2020) morning at 0 a.m., all travelers from the United Kingdom are obliged to register, prior to their trip, on a digital platform allowing, in particular, to fill in the address of their stay in France. This isolation obligation may be lifted from 48 hours, subject to being able to justify a negative test (RT-PCR or antigen).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Employees who work in the goods transport sector, logistic chain, or delivery men (people who can't work remotely) will remain active to ensure business continuity. Industrial warehouses will continue to operate abiding by health regulations. People who cannot work from home such as delivery men will remain worikng as normal but must present upon random inspection proof of business travel (for employees of companies or the public sector) OR an exceptional travel certificate for other non-salaried categories (example: self-employed workers, liberal professions other than health, etc.) Employees of Pays de la Loire must stay home if they are: sick or particularly vulnerable, are one of two parents who care for a child whose school is closed, who have the possibility of working remotely, or who are partially unemployed.

description:
Starting March 19, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health announced the following restrictions for goods transport companies in light of the COVID-19 pandemic
- the hygiene and social distancing measures, known as “barriers”, defined at national level, must be observed by the drivers of transport vehicles as well as by the personnel of the loading places or unloading
- vehicle must be equipped with water, soap, and disposable towels or hydro-alcoholic gel.
- delivery and signature of transport documents are carried out without contact between people.
- In the case of home deliveries, the drivers, after communication with the recipient or his representative, leave the packages at the door by implementing alternative methods which confirm the correct delivery and do not recover the recipient's signature
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
Starting March 19, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has annouced the following rules for drivers of taxis and transport cars in light of the COVID-19 pandemic
- drivers can deny access to the vehicle to anyone showing symptoms of covid-19 infection.
- passengers may not sit next to the driver
- the vehicle is permanently ventilated
- passengers must take all their waste with them.
- the driver performs disinfectant cleaning of the vehicle at least once a day.

description: On the 17 April 2020, the Department of the Marne, located in the Grand Est region of France, annouced new regulations on supermarkets and hypermarkets (large self-service stores). Establishments were required to implement mandatory social distancing, implement a maximum number of customers, manage queues and circulation of customers, all to enable one metre of distance constantly be maintained between shoppers. Establishments also had to take measures to prevent groups of more than two customers forming. These regulations were slated to be in place until the 11 May 2020. Violations were punishable by fines.

description: On the 11 May 2020, the Department of Meurthe-et-Moselle, located in the Grand Est region of France, announced the reopening of all retail businesses excluding restaurants and bars which had been closed under national lockdown policy since March. Entertainment venues such as cinemas, nightclubs and theatres also remained closed. All markets, including food markets, also remained closed. The wearing of masks inside shops was recommended, and the Department specified businesses could make this a condition of entry if they wanted. Driving schools were permitted to re-open.

description: On the 9 May 2020, the Department of Haut-Rhin, located in the Grand Est region of France, announced that all retail businesses except bars, cafés, and restaurants could re-open from the 11 May 2020. Social distancing had to be observed in shops, and the Department also specified there were capacity limits. Businesses were informed they must take measures to regulate and direct foot traffic to maintain social distancing. Food and flower markets were also permitted to re-open. Non-essential retail stores had been closed under the national lockdown of March 17 2020.

description: On the 9 May 2020, the Department of Haut-Rhin, located in the Grand Est region of France, announced that all retail businesses except bars, cafés, and restaurants could re-open from the 11 May 2020. Social distancing had to be observed in shops, and the Department also specified there were capacity limits. Businesses were informed they must take measures to regulate and direct foot traffic to maintain social distancing. Food and flower markets were also permitted to re-open. Non-essential retail stores had been closed under the national lockdown of March 17 2020.

description: From March 14, 2020, the Government of France has prohibited travel and activities that generate public gatherings (commerce, restaurants, shows, cinema, sporting events, salons, etc.) to prevent the spread of the virus. Only essential services remain (food shops, pharmacies, etc.). Other economic activities are not subject to restrictions. UPDATE: On April 25, 2020 France decided to gradually bring the country out of lockdown from May 11. "These include reopening schools, companies returning to work, getting public transport back to normal, the supply of masks and sanitiser, testing policy and support for the elderly."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is closed/locked down

description: On the 26 May 2020, the Department of Meuse in the Grand Est region of France announced that outdoor businesses which facilitated physical or sporitng activites, including skateparks, outdoor paintball, and tree-climbing facilities, were allowed to reopen. Outdoor businesses which did not facilitate a sporting or physical activity, such as theme parks, had to remain closed. The Department also stated that although indoor cinemas still had to remain closed, open-air or drive-in film screening were permitted. These businesses had been closed since the national lockdown of March 17 2020.

description:
"From June 2, 2020 until June 22, 2020, in France, during the second phase of deconfinment, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has annouced that casinos located in green zones can reopen thier slot machines only. The following other conditions apply: 
(1) Patrons have seated places
(2) A minimum distance of one seat is left between the seats occupied by each person or each group of less than ten people coming together or having booked together
(3) Access to areas allowing regroupings is prohibited, except if they are arranged in such a way as to guarantee compliance social distancing and hygeine measures
(4) Masks are mandatory

description:
From June 2, 2020 until June 22, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has mandated that in green departments, marquees, tents, and other like structures may reopen to the public under certain conditions. 
(1) Patrons have seated places
(2) A minimum distance of one seat is left between the seats occupied by each person or each group of less than ten people coming together or having booked together
(3) Access to areas allowing regroupings is prohibited, except if they are arranged in such a way as to guarantee compliance social distancing and hygeine measures
(4) Masks are mandatory, except during the practice of artistic activities

description:
From June 2, 2020 until June 22 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health annouced that in departments classified as green zones, bars, restaurants, and cafés are allowed to reopen under the following conditions: 
(1) groups of no more than 10 per table
(2) minimum of one metre (3.3 feet) between tables, or with a screen in between.
(3) masks mandatory at all times for wait and kitchen staff
(4) masks mandatory for customers when not seated
(5) drinking at the counter in bars is prohibited
(6) seated places only (including in bars)

description:
From June 2, 2020 until June 22 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health annouced that in departments classified as orange zones, bars, restaurants, cafés, and hotel restaturant services are allowed to partially reopen. They may open outdoor terraces and outdoor spaces, continue delivery and take-out activities and room service in hotels restaurants, and may engage in catering under contract. In addition, the following conditions must be met in terraces and outdoor spaces:
(1) groups of no more than 10 per table
(2) minimum of one metre (3.3 feet) between tables, or with a screen in between.
(3) masks mandatory at all times for wait and kitchen staff
(4) masks mandatory for customers when not seated
(5) drinking at the counter in bars is prohibited
(6) seated places only (including in bars)
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: From June 2, 2020 until June 22 in France, in departments designated as orange zones, retail stores and shopping centers with a surface area of greater than 70,000 mˆ2 can open. Masks are recommended for personnel and clients, and these establishments can be closed if rules are not respected. However, the prefect of the department may, after consulting with the mayor, prohibit the opening of a retail store or a shopping center of this size if, due to its location in a heavily populated living area and its immediate proximity to a station served by several rail or guided transport lines and regular public road passenger transport, opening promotes significant population movements.

However, the prefect of the department may, after consulting with the mayor, prohibit the opening of a retail store or a shopping center of this size if, due to its location in a heavily populated living area and its immediate proximity to a station served by several rail or guided transport lines and regular public road passenger transport, opening promotes significant population movements.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_status: This type of business  ("Shopping Centers") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Size of store limited (e.g. stores smaller than 800 sq meters),Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)

description: From June 2, 2020 until June 22, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has annouced that in green zones, open air establishments for sporting purposes (stadiums, arenas, and horserace tracks) can reopen to practicioners only, and must remain closed to the public. Horserace tracks, stadiums, and arenas can only accomodate the people necessay for the organization of horse races or the practice of physical and sporting activities. These activites must be organzed so that 2 meters distance can be maintained at all times. Masks are mandatory except when engaging in physical activity. Community changing rooms and locker rooms must be closed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
2 June 2020, France. Establishments can now open. Following recommendations from medical authority le Haut Conseil de la Santé Publique, the government has not imposed a mandatory four-metre-square limit around each table (as it had previously suggested it might), but restaurants are still required to respect strict rules, including:

10 people maximum per table
At least a metre between tables and groups
Patrons are not allowed to drink or eat standing up at the bar
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of number of customers
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Phase 2 deconfinement in France began on June 2, 2020, with restrictions lifted on bars, cafes, restaurants, travel distances, tourist accommodation, parks, and more. In green zones, bars, cafes, and restaurants have reopened, while in orange zones, only restaurant and bar terraces are permitted to reopen. Hotels, campsites, tourist accommodation such as gites and B&Bs, and holiday villages are now open in green zones, while parks, gardens, forests, watersports centres, lakes, and zoos are now open to the public across the country. Cinemas will stay closed until June 22 everywhere, and weddings in religious sites or Mairies will be allowed.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description:
"From June 22, 2020 in France, and until further notice, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has annouced that restaurants, bars, cafés, and hotel restaurants can reopen across all of France under the following conditions: 
(1) groups of no more than 10 per table
(2) minimum of one metre (3.3 feet) between tables, or with a screen in between.
(3) masks mandatory at all times for wait and kitchen staff
(4) masks mandatory for customers when not seated
(5) drinking at the counter in bars is prohibited
(6) seated places only (including in bars)

description: On September 14, 2020, the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France announced new restrictions and regulations of businesses from September 27, 2020 until October 11, 2020. Bars, restaurants, cafes and general food stores remain closed from 12:30 a.m. to 6:00 a.m.  Multiplication of controls and strengthening of sanctions: a procedure for the systematic closure of all establishments open to the public which do not ensure their customers' respect for barrier gestures is planned.  Refreshments and other standing catering points are prohibited.

description: On 27 September, bars and restaurants in the French port city of Marseille and nearby Aix en Provence closed as a part of local measures to limit the spread of COVID-19. The island of Guadeloupe also saw bars and restaurants shut their doors. These closures came after France's central government toughened measures in eleven French cities, including Paris, where bars must close at 10 pm from 28 September.

description: On Septemeber 5, 2020, the Prefect of the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France repealed this decree and replaced it with new restrictions and regulations of businesses from September 27, 2020 until October 11, 2020. Bars, restaurants, cafes and general food stores remain closed from 12:30 a.m. to 6:00 a.m.  A multiplication of controls and strengthening of sanctions was also legislated: including a procedure for the systematic closure of all establishments open to the public which do not ensure their customers' respect for social distancing was planned, and a ban on refreshments and other standing catering points.

Bars, restaurants, cafes and general food stores remain closed from 12:30 a.m. to 6:00 a.m.  A multiplication of controls and strengthening of sanctions was also legislated: including a procedure for the systematic closure of all establishments open to the public which do not ensure their customers' respect for social distancing was planned, and a ban on refreshments and other standing catering points.

description: Starting on 2 June, 2020, the city of Paris is offering some sidewalks and public spaces as terraces for restaurants, bars and cafes, with compliance with distancing rules and closure by 10pm, until 30 September, 2020. This is to assist businesses who do not have terraces and thus must remain closed until full operations can resume. UPDATE: This has been extended until 30 June, 2021. If the conditions are not respected, the owners of bars and restaurants could be fined from 168 to 500 euros.

description: On October 5 2020, the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France announced the reopening of restaurants in Aix-en-Provence and Marseille. There are restrictions to respect :  - a ban on consumption while standing indoors or outdoors  - a distance of at least one meter between each chair -limit of the number of guests at the same table to six - obligation to wear a mask  -the maximum reception capacity respecting the measures mentioned  - set up a “reminder book” in order to keep the contact details of customers available to health authorities (14 days max).
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: On 23 September, 2020, the Minister of Health classified Paris and its surrounding departments (Hauts-de-Seine, Val-de-Marne, Seine-Saint-Denis) in the enhanced alert zone for COVID-19. As a result, bars and other drinking establishments that primarily sell alcohol must be closed from 10pm to 6am from Monday 28 September. UPDATE: On 5 October, 2020, these departments are classified in the maximum alert zone, resulting in the closure of bars and thus ending the original policy.

description: From 6 October in the morning until 19 October inclusive, there were certain restrictions in Ile-de-France. It includes the closure of all bars, limits restaurant occupancy, prohibits the takeaway sale of alcohol and the consumption of alcohol on public roads from 10 p.m., and prohibits student, wedding, or other private festivities. Additionally, announces the closure of game clubs, dance halls, and game rooms, as well as fairs, exhibitions, and events held in large tents.

description: On 5 October, 2020, Paris and its surrounding departments (Hauts-de-Seine, Val-de-Marne, Seine-Saint-Denis) are classified in the maximum alert zone. As a result, from 6 October, bars and cafes will close for at least two weeks. Restaurants can remain open but making payment at the table is compulsory and tables are limited to a maximum of 6 people. Department stores and shopping centres will accomodate a maximum of one customer per 4 square metres.

description:
From September 22, 2020,  the consumption of alcohol is prohibited from 8 p.m. to 6 a.m. throughout the Rhône department. Bars and restaurants will be permitted to serve patrons only at tables; dancing and drinking standing at the bar will be prohibited. UPDATE: Starting October 9, 2020 "bars, cafes, tea rooms, shisha bars, barges and other drinking establishments in the metropolis of Lyon have to close" 
The minimum end date was set to 15 days.
In addition, restaurants are authorized to receive the public, provided that they comply with strict health protocols. This applies throughout Auvergene-Rhone-Alpes.

description:
"From June 22, 2020 in France, and until further notice, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has annouced that restaurants, bars, cafés, and hotel restaurants can reopen across all of France under the following conditions: 
(1) groups of no more than 10 per table
(2) minimum of one metre (3.3 feet) between tables, or with a screen in between.
(3) masks mandatory at all times for wait and kitchen staff
(4) masks mandatory for customers when not seated
(5) drinking at the counter in bars is prohibited
(6) seated places only (including in bars) UPDATE: From October 30, 2020, most establishments open to the public will be closed: bars and restaurants, shops other than those of first necessity, multi-purpose halls, conference rooms, performance halls and cinemas, sports halls, amusement parks, trade fairs, fairs and exhibitions.

description: On May 2021, the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France announced new regulations of businesses. Activities relating to the rental of beach equipment and the sale of take-out catering are prohibited. Nautical activities and pleasure boating are authorized on condition of respecting on the one hand the general police measures, hygiene and social distancing measures, specific organizational arrangements. Scuba diving clubs' activities and commercial companies that rent pleasure botas or realize commercial services using boats for commercial use can reopen subject to strict compliance with the measures.

description: From August 13, 2021, “the “sanitary pass” is required to attend the following:  “marquees, theaters, sporting or cultural performance venues, conference rooms;  trade shows and exhibition fairs (by exhibition hall);  outdoor establishments including zoological, amusement and theme parks;  stadiums, sports establishments, swimming pools, sports halls;  large casinos, arcades and bowling alleys;  outdoor sit / stand festivals;  cinemas and theaters;  monuments, museums and exhibition halls;  libraries, media libraries (excluding university and specialized libraries, BPI, BnF);  sports competition ;  other events, cultural, sporting, fun or festive, organized in public space or in a place open to the public and likely to give rise to control of the access of people.  worship establishments for events not of a religious nature;  ships and boats, cruise ship type  in discotheques, dance clubs and bars.  in fairgrounds, from a threshold of 30 stands or attractions.”  “commercial catering activities (bars and restaurants, including the terraces), with the exception of catering or takeaway ready meals, road professional catering (based on a list approved by decree prefectural) and rail, room service in hotel restaurants and bars and non-commercial catering, in particular the free distribution of meals;”
