description:
In the public service in France, article 44 of law n°84-53 of January 26, 1984 prescribes that the aptitude lists are valid for a period of four years following the public service exam date.
Thus, on March 28, 2020 (announced on March 27, 2020), the President of France suspended the countdown of the validity period of these lists from March 12, 2020 until the end of the public health emergency, increased by two months to take into account the public health crisis.

description: On March 15, 2020, the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France announced regulations for municipal elections from March 15, 2020 until March 22, 2020. These regulations included the cleaning of election materials, the arrangement of polling stations and management of waiting files, the display of "barrier measures" at the entrance to polling stations, the obligation of wearing a mask for people whose medical situation requires it, 14 municipalities have changed the opening hours of their polling stations and special arrangements for a relaxation of the rules for voting proxies.

description: On March 15, 2020, the Ministry of Justice of France announced that from March 16, 2020, public reception services and houses of justice can no longer receive the public. The agents of these services answer by telephone to emergency situations. Furthermore, all non-urgent hearings are postponed. The exceptions are: emergency criminal hearings; presentations before the investigating judge and the liberty and detention judge; emergency hearings for child custody; the prosecution service and emergency procedures before the civil judge, in particular for the eviction of a violent spouse.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 15, 2020, the President of France signed the Ordinance No. 2020-430 which requires civil servants and contractual agents of public law in the public service to take ten days off during the period of the health emergency. Five of those day offs have to be between March 16, 2020 and April 16, 2020 and the five other days of reduced working time have to be between April 17, 2020 and the end of the health emergency declared by Law of March 23, 2020.

description: From March 17, 2020 until April 5, 2020, in France, the Minister of Solidarity and Health has suspended all national competitive exams for public and private education and tests contributing to the recruitment, advancement and promotion of public servants and magistrates. The exams can take place online if the nature of the tests and the conditions of their organization allow it. UPDATE: The policy is annulled. Article 11 of the Order of March 23, 2020 prescribing the organizational and operational measures of the health system necessary to deal with the covid-19 epidemic in the context of the public health emergency repealed article 4 of the Order of March 17 regarding the suspension of national competitive exams for public and private education and tests contributing to the recruitment, avancement and promotion of public servants and magistrates.

description: From April 4, 2020 (announced April 3) until the expiration of a period of one month from the date of cessation of the health emergency declared under the conditions of article 4 of the aforementioned law of 23 March 2020, the Ministry of Justice declared that notaries are allowed to draw up a notarial deed in electronic format when one or all of the parties or any other person contributing to the deed are neither present nor represented. The notary must collect consent and the electronic signature of all parties contributing to the notarial deed.

description:
On April 6 2020, the Department of Vosges in the Grand Est region of France banned aircraft without passengers (including drones) from flying over high density population areas and towns or other population centres in Vosges due to the limitations on movement caused by the Covid-19 lockdown. 
Exemptions were made for: 
- government aircraft or aircraft chartered by the government 
- rescue, security and emergency aircraft 
- telecommunications maintenance aircraft. 
Violations were punishable by fines and misuse of a drone was punishable by a 750,000 euro fine. The ban was in place until April 30 2020.

description: On April 28, 2020, the Prime Minister of France announced that beaches will remain close at least until June 1st, 2020. The decree No. 2020-545 of May 11, 2020 prohibits access to beaches and lakes. Likewise, nautical and recreational activities are prohibited. However, the representative of the State may, on a proposal from a mayor, authorize access to beaches and lakes and nautical activities if a physical distance of at least one meter between two people is observed and if the gathering does not count more than 10 people.

description:
From May 11, the prefecture of Corse-du-Sud has reopened with new methods of welcoming the public. 
(1) Prefecture access will be limited to those with appointments; waiting for an appointment inside the prefecture is prohibited. 
(2) The digital point located in reception will be accessible without an appointment from Monday to Friday from 8:30 a.m. to 11:30 a.m. and from 1:30 p.m. to 3:30 p.m for people who have difficulty carrying out digital procedures relating to vehicle registration certificates or driving licenses. Only one person can access the digital point at a time.

description: On the 19 March 2020, the Department of Ardennes in the Grand Est region of France banned the collecting or cutting of wood in forests throughout the region. Sports and recreational activities, foraging/fruit picking, photography, and recreational fishing in forests were also banned. UPDATE: On the 9 May 2020, the Department of Ardennes in the Grand Est region of France announced that from the 11 May 2020, residents could access walking and cycle paths, canal banks, marked hiking trails, waterways, leisure centres, woods, and forests, provided they were within 100km of the residence and social distancing was maintained.

description: Sécurité Routière (Road Safety) announced a gradual resumption of activities in the traffic education sector from 11 May, 2020. From 11 May, 2020, theoretical and practical training resumed and some driving schools reopened; from 25 May, 2020, heavyweight (C and D) and motorcycle (A and A1) tests resumed; and from 8 June, 2020, category B driving license exams resumed. On May 31, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-663 which allowed closed establishments mentioned in Book II of the Highway Code, from June 2nd, 2020 to welcome the public to dispense the training for the obtention of a driving license if these establishments can't insure this training remotely. UPDATE: The original policy announced that activities of motor driving license inspectors, and therefore practical and theoretical driving license exams, are interrupted for an indefinite period. Sécurité Routière (Road Safety) announced a gradual resumption of activities in the traffic education sector from 11 May, 2020. From 11 May, 2020, theoretical and practical training resumed and some driving schools reopened; from 25 May, 2020, heavyweight (C and D) and motorcycle (A and A1) tests resumed; and from 8 June, 2020, category B driving license exams resumed. On May 31, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-663 which allowed closed establishments mentioned in Book II of the Highway Code, from June 2nd, 2020 to welcome the public to dispense the training for the obtention of a driving license if these establishments can't insure this training remotely.

description:
On the 15 May 2020, the Department of Vosges in the Grand Est region of France decreed that access to certain beaches, man-made lakes, natural lakes and their foreshores, which had been restricted in Vosges under national laws since 23 March 2020, would be restored.
- in the commune of Contrexéville two lakes were opened for fishing, jogging, cycling and bike-riding 
- in the commune of Xonrupt-Longemer one lake was opened for fishing (on the foreshore and on boats) as well as the renting of small boats and pedal boats 
- in the commune of Gérardmer one lake was opened for commercial boat renting (including launches and small boats), private boat launching, fishing, and sports activities
- in the communes of Chaumosey, Girancourt, Renauvoid, Sanchey, the Lac de Bouzey was opened for fishing, and paths and foreshores would be open for exercise
- in the commune of Médonville the communal pond was open for fishing - in the commune of Saulxures-les-Bulgnéville the communal pond was opened for fishing
- in the commune of Saulxures-et-Moselette outdoor leisure centres were opened for fishing and walking/individual exercise
- in the commune of Essegney, the communal pond was opened for fishing and walking 
- in the commune of Chamagne, the Plein Bonhomme Pond was opened for fishing 
- in the commune of Girmont Val d'Ajol, the Villerain Pond was opened for fishing
Violations of the decree were punishable by fines.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: On May 15th 2020, the Department of Gironde announced the relaxation of mass gathering restrictions, permitting nautical and leisure activities on beaches, lakes, and other such water areas, provided that no more than 10 people could gather together, on land as well as on a single watercraft. This relaxation of restrictions would last from May 16th 2020 until June 2nd 2020, and would apply to beaches in the communes of Audenge, Andernos-les-Bains, Lège-Cap-Ferret, Arcachon, Gujan-Mestras, Lanton, Arès, Le Porge, Naujac-sur-Mer, Grayan-et-l’Hôpital, Vendays-Montalivet, Vensac, Soulac-sur-Mer, Hourtin, La Teste-de-Buch, Lacanau, Carcans, and Le Verdon-sur-Mer; to lakes in the communes of Hourtin, La Teste-de-Buch, Lacanau, and Carcans; and to other water areas in La Teste-de-Buch and Le Teich.

description: On May 15th 2020, the Department of Gironde announced the relaxation of mass gathering restrictions, permitting nautical and leisure activities on beaches, lakes, and other such water areas, provided that no more than 10 people could gather together, on land as well as on a single watercraft. This relaxation of restrictions would last from May 16th 2020 until June 2nd 2020, and would apply to beaches in the communes of Audenge, Andernos-les-Bains, Lège-Cap-Ferret, Arcachon, Gujan-Mestras, Lanton, Arès, Le Porge, Naujac-sur-Mer, Grayan-et-l’Hôpital, Vendays-Montalivet, Vensac, Soulac-sur-Mer, Hourtin, La Teste-de-Buch, Lacanau, Carcans, and Le Verdon-sur-Mer; to lakes in the communes of Hourtin, La Teste-de-Buch, Lacanau, and Carcans; and to other water areas in La Teste-de-Buch and Le Teich.

description: On March 20, 2020, the police prefect of Paris, France, announced a further restriction on outdoor spaces by banning all travel and gatherings on the riversides of the Seine, the lawns of the Esplanade des Invalides and Champ-de-Mars, for the weekend starting 20 March. UPDATE: On May 19 2020, the government of the Hauts-de-Seine department in Ile-de-France, France, announced it has received authorization to reopening of the Vallons de la Bièvre promenade since May 18, open only on weekdays as a route reserved for mobility between work and home. It is not open for walkers and remains closed in the weekend.

description:
On the 15 May 2020, the Department of Vosges in the Grand Est region of France decreed that access to certain beaches, man-made lakes, natural lakes and their foreshores, which had been restricted in Vosges under national laws since 23 March 2020, would be restored.
- in the commune of Contrexéville two lakes were opened for fishing, jogging, cycling and bike-riding 
- in the commune of Xonrupt-Longemer one lake was opened for fishing (on the foreshore and on boats) as well as the renting of small boats and pedal boats 
- in the commune of Gérardmer one lake was opened for commercial boat renting (including launches and small boats), private boat launching, fishing, and sports activities
- in the communes of Chaumosey, Girancourt, Renauvoid, Sanchey, the Lac de Bouzey was opened for fishing, and paths and foreshores would be open for exercise
- in the commune of Médonville the communal pond was open for fishing - in the commune of Saulxures-les-Bulgnéville the communal pond was opened for fishing
- in the commune of Saulxures-et-Moselette outdoor leisure centres were opened for fishing and walking/individual exercise
- in the commune of Essegney, the communal pond was opened for fishing and walking 
- in the commune of Chamagne, the Plein Bonhomme Pond was opened for fishing 
- in the commune of Girmont Val d'Ajol, the Villerain Pond was opened for fishing
Violations of the decree were punishable by fines. UPDATE: On the 20 May 2020, the Department of Vosges in the Grand Est region of France decreed that access to more lakes would be restored. Access and permitted activities different between communes:
- in the commune of Midrevaux, the communal pond was opened for fishing
- in the commune of Socourt, 13 ballasts were opened for fishin
- in the commune of Bulgnéville, the Lac des Récollets was opened for fishing and walking
- in the commune of Langley, the communal pond was opened for fishing 
- in the commune of Celles sur Plaine, the Lac de la Plaine was opened for fishing 
- in the commune of Remirement, one man-made lake was opened for fishing - in the commune of Rupt sue Moselle, the ponds at Saulx and Hachamps were opened for fishing. 
Violations of these regultions were punisable by fines.

description: On the 3 April 2020, the Department of Meuse in the Grand Est region of France banned public access to parks, public gardens, gravel pits (former open-cut mines used for recreation purposes), forests, lakes, river banks, playgrounds, fitness trails, and sports grounds until the 15 April 2020. UPDATE: On the 26 May 2020, the Department of Meuse in the Grand Est region of France announced that professional freshwater fishers were allowed to fish in lakes and dams, provided they respected social distancing measures and did not gather in groups of 10 or more. Both recreational and professional fishing was allowed at outdoor public fishing infrastructure adjacent to freshwater water bodies.

description: On March 17, 2020 in France, the Minister of the Interior postponed the second round of municipal and community elections, of Paris councilors and of Lyon metropolitan councilors for the approximately 4,922 "communes" whose city ​​councilors were not fully appointed in the first round. The second round was initially set for March 22, 2020, but no new date has been given yet. UPDATE: On May 27, 2020, the President of France announced the postponement of the second round of municipal and community elections, of Paris councilors, and of Lyon metropolitan councilors to June 28, 2020. The original policy didn't set a date, but mentioned that the new date of the election should be set by decree on May 27 2020.

description: On May 20 2020, the Department of Haut-Rhin in the Grand Est region of France announced that specific ponds and lakes (see annex) would be opened solely for recreational fishing. Fishers were required to maintain three metres of distance between each other, not to exchange any material, to respect road markings allowing for pedestrian access, and not to hold any social activities such as picnics or barbecues. description: On May 31, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-663, which allowed establishments of category L (hearing, conference, meeting, performance or multipurpose rooms) to open in green departments from June 2, 2020 under three conditions (first, mask wearing is mandatory in these establishments for people over 11 years old. Furthermore, the managers of these establishments must ensure that the people welcomed have a seat and that a minimum distance of one seat is left between the seats occupied by each person or each group of less than ten people coming together or having booked together). The same decree prohibited hearing, conference, meeting, performance or multipurpose rooms to open except for courtrooms in orange departments from June 2, 2020.

description: Lyon, France. On June 2nd, the city of Lyon reopened all 16 city libraries. Patrons are required to wear masks, use hand sanitizer, and follow the arrows directing foot traffic. To reduce the possibility of transmission, the number of items available for checkout has changed from 20 items due after 3 weeks to 10 items due after 6 weeks. Additionally, all study rooms will remain closed.

description: On May 31, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-663, which allows, from June 2nd, 2020, campsites and trailer parks to open to the public in green departments, but those in orange departments remain closed except for caravans or recreational vehicles that are considered permanent homes for the people who live there (Category PA). UPDATE: The original policy had set the closure of campsites to April 15, 2020. It was then extended to May 11, 2020. It was again extended on May 11, 2020 but no end date was given. On May 31, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-663, which allows, from June 2nd, 2020, campsites and trailer parks to open to the public in green departments, but those in orange departments remain closed except for caravans or recreational vehicles that are considered permanent homes for the people who live there (Category PA).

On May 31, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-663, which allows the competent authority to open beaches, lakes and nautical activity centers from June 2, 2020. A physical distance of at least one meter between two people must be observed and the gathering shouldn't count more than 10 people. UPDATE: The original policy prohibited access to beaches and lakes and prohibited nautical activities from April 28, 2020 until June 1st, 2020.

From June 2nd, 2020, the competent authority will be allowed to open beaches, lakes and nautical activity centers. A physical distance of at least one meter between two people must be observed and the gathering shouldn't count more than 10 people.

description: On June 17, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-742, which facilitates vote by proxy for the second round of the general renewal of municipal and community councilors, Paris councilors and Lyon metropolitan councilors set on June 28, 2020. Therefore, people who, due to the Covid-19 pandemic, cannot appear before the judicial police officers and agents empowered to establish powers of attorney or their delegates have the right to have the competent authorities come to establish or withdraw their power of attorney. The people mentioned in the previous paragraph may refer the matter to the competent authorities by post, by telephone or, where appropriate, by electronic means. These people indicate the reason for their inability to travel, without having to provide proof. The judicial police officers and agents empowered to establish the powers of attorney, or the delegates of these judicial police officers as well as the people whose power of attorney is obtained wear a mask

Mask wearing is still mandatory for people older than 11 years old. However, museums cannot admit more people than the number of people required so that each person has a 4 square meter space. In addition, when local circumstances justify it, the prefect of a department may limit the maximum number of people who can be admitted in these establishments.

description: On November 18, 2020, the President of France signed Ordinance No. 2020-1401, which extends the authorization to contravene article 706-71 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and to use an audiovisual telecommunication means before all criminal courts without it being necessary to obtain the agreement of the parties.This is to last from November 19, 2020 until one month following the end of the state of health emergency declared by the decree of October 14, 2020. UPDATE: The original policy authorized, from March 26, 2020, to contravene article 706-71 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and to use an audiovisual telecommunication means before all criminal courts without it being necessary to obtain the agreement of the parties. This is to last from November 19, 2020 until one month following the end of the state of health emergency declared by the decree of October 14, 2020. UPDATE: The original policy authorized hearings of administrative jurisdictions to be held using audiovisual telecommunication means that guarantee the identity of the parties and guarantee the quality of transmission and the confidentiality of exchanges between the parties and their lawyers from March 26, 2020. description: On November 27, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1454, which extends the closure of establishments of category L (hearing, conference, meeting, performance and multipurpose rooms). However, courtrooms, crematoriums and rooms for activities of professional artists are allowed to remain open. However, the managers of these establishments must ensure that the people welcomed have a seat and that a minimum distance of one seat is left between the seats occupied by each person or each group of less than six people coming together or having booked together. Mask wearing is mandatory for people older than 11 years old. This is to last from November 28, 2020, but no end date has been given. UPDATE: The original policy set the closure of establishments of category L (hearing, conference, meeting, performance and multipurpose rooms) to December1, 2020. On November 27, 2020 it was extended but no end date was given.

description:
On December 24, 2020, the President of France signed Ordinance No. 2020-1694, which extends the suspension of the four-year validity period of the aptitude lists in the public service required under article 44 of the Law of January 26, 1984, from January 1, 2021 to April 30, 2021.
 UPDATE: The original policy fixed the suspension of the four-year validity period of the aptitude lists in the public service required under article 44 of the Law of January 26, 1984 from March 12, 2020 until the end of the public health emergency, increased by two months. On December 24, 2020, the President of France extended the suspension from January 1, 2021 to April 30, 2021.

description: On February 3rd, 2021, the President of France signed Ordinance No. 2021-112, which authorizes career military personnel who have reached the age limit and contract military personnel who have reached the term of service limit to be retained in service for a maximum of one year due to the pandemic.This ordinance also authorizes former professional soldiers who had been struck off the roll for less than three years to return to service until they reach the age limit.These measures are expected to remain in effect for a period of six months after the end of the current state of health emergency.

UPDATE: On June 2 2021, the Department of the Marne in the Grand Est region of France extended the ban on the consumption of alcohol in all public places until June 30 2021. An exception was made for alcoholic beverages consumed and bought in outdoor spaces of businesses possessing liquor licenses level III or IV, or accompanying a meal.

description: On February 28, 2020, the French government announced that: in general, indoor gatherings of more than 5,000 people are prohibited in France. In the most affected area north of Paris, all public gatherings are banned. "The government has also banned all public gatherings in Oise, north of Paris, and in La Balme-de-Sillingy, a town in the French Alps where cases have been reported."   "In the department of Oise, the main outbreak, and in the town of La Balme-de-Sillingy, in the Haute-Savoie region, all public gatherings - including masses - are banned 'until further notice'."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
From March 9, 2020 unti April 15, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has banned any gathering bringing together more than 1,000 people simultaneously in a closed or open environment on national territory.

Gatherings essential to the continuity of the life of the Nation may be maintained by way of derogation by the State representative in the department, by regulatory or individual measures, except when local circumstances preclude it. The State representative is empowered for the same purposes, by regulatory or individual measures, to prohibit or restrict meetings, gatherings or activities not falling under the first paragraph when local circumstances so require.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

update_level_var: Volume of policy strengthening ; timing of policy strengthening
description:
From March 9, 2020 unti April 15, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has banned any gathering bringing together more than 1,000 people simultaneously in a closed or open environment on national territory.

Gatherings essential to the continuity of the life of the Nation may be maintained by way of derogation by the State representative in the department, by regulatory or individual measures, except when local circumstances preclude it. The State representative is empowered for the same purposes, by regulatory or individual measures, to prohibit or restrict meetings, gatherings or activities not falling under the first paragraph when local circumstances so require. UPDATE: On April 14, 2020, the ban on gatherings of 100 people was extended until May 11, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: As of April 8, 2020, in the region Ile-de-France, France, six departments restricted sportive activities during the lockdown period. These activities would be banned between 10h and 19h. The departments are Yvelines, Hauts-de-Seine, Val-d'Oise, Seine-et-Marne, Val-de Marne and Paris. description:
On March 16, 2020, the president of the republic announced that from Tuesday, March 17, 2020, it is forbidden to see anyone (except for work, food shopping, health issues and playing outdoor sports alone), hence the ban on meeting outside of household members and work colleagues.
Failure to produce one will result in a 38-euro fine, which may rise to 135 euros at a later stage. UPDATE: "On May 10, 2020, the French regained the right to leave their homes after nearly two months of lockdown." The prohibition of meetings outside the household and work thus ceased.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 11, 2020, the transport company RATP (Self-governance Paris transport) announced that passenger capacity will remain severely limited: in order to respect social distancing rules, RATP wants to limit ridership to 15% of normal levels. Passengers at peak times will have to provide a certificate from their employer justifying their travel.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 11 May 2020, there are some changes and restrictions in France. Funeral ceremonies will have a new limit of 20 people allowed to attend, other gatherings are kept to a maximum of 10 people. UPDATE: Until the 2nd of June, weddings and baptisms are not allowed to take place.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 27 2020, the Department of Meurthe-et-Moselle in the Grand Est region of France announced that in all 20 communes of the intercommunal conglomeration of Grand Nancy, any gatherings of more than 2 people over the age of 10 were prohibited between the hours of 10pm and 5am. The ban excluded giving/receiving care and travelling for work or other activities deemed essential. UPDATE: On April 22 2020, the Department of Meurthe-et-Moselle in the Grand Est region of France announced the ban on gatherings of more than two people aged over 10 years old in the intercommunal conglomeration of Grand Nancy from 10pm to 5am would end on May 11 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries

description: Starting from 12 May, there will be an alcohol ban. Police in the French capital declared a ban on alcoholic drinks on the banks of the Seine and the popular Canal Saint-Martin after crowds gathered there on 11 May evening to enjoy their newly recovered freedom following eight weeks of lockdown. The Paris mayor has called for face masks to be made obligatory throughout the city.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: In France, from May 23, 2020, the National Government has announced that gatherings and meetings in places of worship are allowed to resume, but only under certain conditions. Attendance must be limited to a maximum threshold such that all who attend can maintain a distance of at least one meter between two people. Masks are mandatory for all those in attendance aged 11 or older, and hand disinfection will be mandatory at the entrance to places of worship. The departmental prefect can prohibit these gatherings if these conditions are not met.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On June 4, 2020, the president of the republic announced that this year the traditional July 14 military parade is cancelled due to social distancing requirements related to the coronavirus, and will be replaced by a ceremony to honor medical personnel on the front lines of the fight against the pandemic.
Instead of the traditional parade of soldiers and the exhibition of military equipment on the Champs-Elysées, a much more modest ceremony will be organized this year on the Place de la Concorde, where the parade normally ends.

description:
On July 27 2020, the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France announced special conditions for the celebration of the festival of Eid al-Adha (held on July 30, August 1, and August 2 2020). 
The conditions were as followed: 
- permission from the department was needed to carry out animal sacrifice 
- anyone planning on sacrificing an animal had to abide by social distancing guidelines. 
People celebrating the holiday were encouraged to purchase meat from an animal slaughtered during Eid al-Adha from a butchers of supermarkets, and more abbatoirs were authorised to carry out ritual sacrifices of livestock to enable this.

description: This year's delayed three-week Tour de France race starts on Saturday, 29 August and runs until 20 September. All team members have to undergo two diagnostic tests for Covid-19, six days and three days ahead of the start, while they have to compile a health check questionnaire twice a day during the race. Riders and team staff will be in a bubble from the day they arrive in Nice before the Grand Depart. They will be tested twice before the race starts, and a mobile testing lab will also be available. If a team has two positive cases or [members] with strong symptoms within a seven-day period, they will be out of the race.

description: On September 14, 2020, Marseille and Aix-en-Provence limit public gatherings to 1000 and put additional restrictions on private gatherings. That limit covers places like stadiums and concert halls, as well as demonstrations. Cafes and restaurants will also no longer be able to serve clients who are standing up and will not be able to play music outdoors. Dancing is forbidden in public venues, including at weddings.  In these regions including Bordeaux, the government officials announced a ban on gatherings of more than 10 people in public parks, along the citys picturesque river and on beaches. Fun fairs, antique fairs and neighborhood parties are also banned.The regional government also asked Bordeaux residents to limit private family gatherings, singling out weddings, to a maximum of 10 people.

description:
On September 14 2020, the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France announced new restrictions on mass gatherings. 
In communes throughout the department with a rate of Covid-19 infections surpassing 100 per 100,000 people, all major events, such as Neighbours' Day, the Marseille Fair, and celebrations of European patrimony were cancelled. UPDATE: On September 27 2020, this Prefect of Bouches-du-Rhône repealed this policy.

description: On September 14, 2020,the department of Bordeaux has lowered the 5000-person limit for public gatherings (that are applied nationwide) down to 1000. UPDATE: On September 28, 2020, in Bordeaux, the top government official for the region announced a ban on gatherings of more than 10 people in public parks, along the city’s picturesque river and on beaches. Also banned are fun fairs, antique fairs and neighborhood parties. The new rules also limit the size of large public gatherings to no more than 1,000 people, below the national benchmark of 5,000 people. That limit covers places like stadiums and concert halls, as well as demonstrations.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description:
On October 29th 2020, the French government announced that:
I. - The establishments of worship, falling under category V (Establishments in which the number of members of the public does not reach the minimum figure set by the safety regulations for each type of operation), are authorized to remain open. Any gathering or meeting within them is prohibited except for funeral ceremonies up to a limit of 30 people.
II. - Anyone eleven years of age or over who accesses or remains in these establishments wears a protective mask.
The obligation to wear a mask does not prevent it from being temporarily removed for the performance of the rites that require it.
III. - The manager of the place of worship ensures at all times, and in particular when entering and leaving the building, that the provisions mentioned in this article are respected.
IV. - The departmental prefect may, after formal notice remains unanswered, prohibit the reception of the public in religious establishments if the conditions of their organization as well as the controls put in place are not such as to guarantee compliance with the provisions. mentioned in this article.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
On Tuesday, November 17, 2020, President Emmanuel Macron, who was meeting with stakeholders in the world of sports in France at the Élysée Palace, clarified that the return of the public "is not conceivable in December" of the year 2020. Thus, the public will be able to return to the sports venues only from the beginning of 2021, provided that the health situation continues to improve. UPDATE: Starting May 19, spectators in outdoor sports facilities (stadiums) are allowed again: 35% of the workforce, up to 1,000 people (seated, not standing); 
practitioners in outdoor sports establishments (stadiums): priority audiences such as schools.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting May 19, spectators in outdoor sports facilities (stadiums) are allowed again: "35% of the workforce, up to 1,000 people (seated, not standing); practitioners in outdoor sports establishments (stadiums): priority audiences such as schools." description: On January 22 2020, in France, the Mission COREB (Coordination Opérationnelle Risque Epidémique et Biologique) nationale informed the protocol that 1st line should follow when treating patients suspected of having COVID-19.These are, if patient had symptoms (fever and couph): give them a face mask; search for any symptoms of severity, possible comorbidities. Sympthomatic treatment, if vital emergency. Make a clinical-epidemiological analysis to estimate the diagnostic probability. In case of being a possible result , call the infectiologist of the health facilities and alert the ARS (Agence Régionale de Santé). If patient remains suspect,treat for few hours at ES of first contact, precautions above maintained until classification; adapted treatment of possible alternative. Also includes questions that 1st line medical staff should ask patients.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_province: China: Beijing,Guangdong,Henan,Shaanxi,Shanxi; Japan: Tokyo; South Korea: Seoul; Thailand: Bangkok
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On March 11 2020, the French Health Minister suspended all visitations to all aged-care homes (Établissement d'hébergement pour personnes âgées dépendantes, EHPAD) and long-term care units (unités de soins de longue durée, USLD) across the country. Visitation to auntonomous residents was also highly discouraged. Exceptions could be made by the director of the establishment, based on the advice of Regional Health Agencies or Prefectures. 
This policy is in effect until further notice.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

description:
From Monday March 16, 2020 in France, the Minister of the Ecological and Inclusive Transition and the Secretary of State for the Minister of Ecological and Inclusive Transition annouced that in order to limit travel as much as possible, traffic will be reduced to the following:
METRO: 80% of the insured traffic.
BUS and TRAM: almost normal traffic.
RER A and B: normal traffic.
TGV / TER / TRANSILIEN: 7 trains out of 10.

description:
Starting March 19, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health announced the following restrictions for goods transport companies in light of the COVID-19 pandemic
- the hygiene and social distancing measures, known as “barriers”, defined at national level, must be observed by the drivers of transport vehicles as well as by the personnel of the loading places or unloading
- vehicle must be equipped with water, soap, and disposable towels or hydro-alcoholic gel.
- delivery and signature of transport documents are carried out without contact between people.
- In the case of home deliveries, the drivers, after communication with the recipient or his representative, leave the packages at the door by implementing alternative methods which confirm the correct delivery and do not recover the recipient's signature
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Transportation (land; water and air)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
From March 19, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Soldidarity and Health is mandating that all bus and train operators take the following social distancing measures: 
- take all appropriate measures to separate the driver from travelers by a distance of at least one meter and inform travelers (unless proven technically impossible)
- prohibit travelers from using the front door in vehciles with multiple doors, and allow them to enter and exit through any other door. 
- permit use of the front door when arrangements have been made to separate the driver from travelers by a distance of at least one meter
In the event of non-compliance with these social distancing measures, a ban may be placed on transport service on all the lines concerned.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keep a distance of some other distance not listed above. Please note the distance in meters in the text entry.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: On March 17 2020 the French Minister of Justice announced that effective from March 18 2020, all visitors would be banned from all French prisons for fifteen days (until March 31 2020). description: On the 17 April 2020, the Department of the Marne, located in the Grand Est region of France, annouced new regulations on supermarkets and hypermarkets (large self-service stores). Establishments were required to implement mandatory social distancing, implement a maximum number of customers, manage queues and circulation of customers, all to enable one metre of distance constantly be maintained between shoppers. Establishments also had to take measures to prevent groups of more than two customers forming. These regulations were slated to be in place until the 11 May 2020. Violations were punishable by fines.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Supermarkets/grocery stores
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries

description: On the 19 April 2020, French Health Minister Olivier Véran annouced family members could visit relatives in aged-care facilities again from April 20 2020 with certain conditions had to be respected, including maintaining hand hygiene, wearing a mask, maitining social distancing (1m in between each person), and holding meetings in gardens of designated rooms.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

description:
On March 11 2020, the French Health Minister suspended all visitations to all aged-care homes (Établissement d'hébergement pour personnes âgées dépendantes, EHPAD) and long-term care units (unités de soins de longue durée, USLD) across the country. Visitation to auntonomous residents was also highly discouraged. Exceptions could be made by the director of the establishment, based on the advice of Regional Health Agencies or Prefectures. 
This policy is in effect until further notice. UPDATE: On the 19 April 2020, French Health Minister Olivier Véran annouced family members could visit relatives in aged-care facilities again from April 20 2020 with certain conditions had to be respected, including maintaining hand hygiene, wearing a mask, maitining social distancing (1m in between each person), and holding meetings in gardens of designated rooms.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

description: On April 28, 2020, the French Prime Minister announced that every second seat should be condemned in order to enforce social distancing guidelines and starting April 29, 2020, the RATP (Régie Autonome des Transports Parisiens/Autonomous Parisian Transportation Administration) agents have started to affix stickers to every two seats on RATP platforms, while others appear on seats inside buses, trains and subways along with social distancing reminders on windows and floors of buses, trains, and subways on the RATP network.

description: On May 11, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-545, which authorized the public to access parks and gardens in green departments only if a physical distance of at least one meter between two people is observed and if the gathering does not count more than 10 people. The same decree prohibited the public to access parks and gardens in red departments.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On the 11 May 2020, the Department of Meurthe-et-Moselle, located in the Grand Est region of France, announced the reopening of all retail businesses excluding restaurants and bars which had been closed under national lockdown policy since March. Entertainment venues such as cinemas, nightclubs and theatres also remained closed. All markets, including food markets, also remained closed. The wearing of masks inside shops was recommended, and the Department specified businesses could make this a condition of entry if they wanted. Driving schools were permitted to re-open.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries

description: On the 9 May 2020, the Department of Haut-Rhin, located in the Grand Est region of France, announced that all retail businesses except bars, cafés, and restaurants could re-open from the 11 May 2020. Social distancing had to be observed in shops, and the Department also specified there were capacity limits. Businesses were informed they must take measures to regulate and direct foot traffic to maintain social distancing. Food and flower markets were also permitted to re-open. Non-essential retail stores had been closed under the national lockdown of March 17 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries

description: From May 11, 2020 until June 2 in France, retail stores and shopping centers with a surface area of greater than 40,000 mˆ2 can reopen with strict health and safety guidelines. description:
On May 7 2020, the French government confirmed that public tranposrt users in the Île-de-France region will have to present a professional certificate or a compelling reason to travel during rush hour when public tranport re-opens on May 11. 
Permitted reasons include: 
1. Travel for work which cannot be postponed.
2. Travel to school or to an exam.
3. Travel for medical appointments that cannot be completed through video meetings.
4. Travel for urgent family reasons including caring for children or a vulnerable individual.
5. Travel to court or police station
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Starting May 11 2020, the French national government has declared that anyone that is 11 years of age or over who boards a ship must wear a mask. Otherwise, access to the ship is refused.
This obligation applies in publicly accessible areas of ferry terminals and waiting areas.
This obligation does not apply to passengers who remain in their vehicles on board the ship or boat when authorized to do so.

description:
On April 30, 2020, French government announced the plan to encourage people to take their bikes instead of public transport after a nationwide coronavirus lockdown ends on May 11. People can benefit from a subsidy of up to 50 euros to fix them and from free training to learn to ride safely, with an experienced instructor. Objective is to reduce overcrowding in metros and buses, where it is hard to practice the social distancing required to prevent virus transmission. 
The €50 subsidy, initially available until the end of 2020, is available until March 31st 2021, Environment Minister Barbara Pompili said on November 30th 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions ridership of other forms of public transportation (please include details in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 15th 2020, the Department of Gironde announced the relaxation of mass gathering restrictions, permitting nautical and leisure activities on beaches, lakes, and other such water areas, provided that no more than 10 people could gather together, on land as well as on a single watercraft. This relaxation of restrictions would last from May 16th 2020 until June 2nd 2020, and would apply to beaches in the communes of Audenge, Andernos-les-Bains, Lège-Cap-Ferret, Arcachon, Gujan-Mestras, Lanton, Arès, Le Porge, Naujac-sur-Mer, Grayan-et-l’Hôpital, Vendays-Montalivet, Vensac, Soulac-sur-Mer, Hourtin, La Teste-de-Buch, Lacanau, Carcans, and Le Verdon-sur-Mer; to lakes in the communes of Hourtin, La Teste-de-Buch, Lacanau, and Carcans; and to other water areas in La Teste-de-Buch and Le Teich.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Beaches
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries

description:

(1) Patrons have seated places
(2) A minimum distance of one seat is left between the seats occupied by each person or each group of less than ten people coming together or having booked together
(3) Access to areas allowing regroupings is prohibited, except if they are arranged in such a way as to guarantee compliance social distancing and hygeine measures
(4) Masks are mandatory

description:
"From June 2, 2020 until June 22, 2020, in France, during the second phase of deconfinment, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has annouced that casinos located in green zones can reopen thier slot machines only. The following other conditions apply: 
(1) Patrons have seated places
(2) A minimum distance of one seat is left between the seats occupied by each person or each group of less than ten people coming together or having booked together
(3) Access to areas allowing regroupings is prohibited, except if they are arranged in such a way as to guarantee compliance social distancing and hygeine measures
(4) Masks are mandatory
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
From June 2, 2020 until June 22, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has mandated that in green departments, marquees, tents, and other like structures may reopen to the public under certain conditions. 
(1) Patrons have seated places
(2) A minimum distance of one seat is left between the seats occupied by each person or each group of less than ten people coming together or having booked together
(3) Access to areas allowing regroupings is prohibited, except if they are arranged in such a way as to guarantee compliance social distancing and hygeine measures
(4) Masks are mandatory, except during the practice of artistic activities

description:
From June 2, 2020 until June 22 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health annouced that in departments classified as green zones, bars, restaurants, and cafés are allowed to reopen under the following conditions: 
(1) groups of no more than 10 per table
(2) minimum of one metre (3.3 feet) between tables, or with a screen in between.
(3) masks mandatory at all times for wait and kitchen staff
(4) masks mandatory for customers when not seated
(5) drinking at the counter in bars is prohibited
(6) seated places only (including in bars)
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
From June 2, 2020 until June 22 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health annouced that in departments classified as orange zones, bars, restaurants, cafés, and hotel restaturant services are allowed to partially reopen. They may open outdoor terraces and outdoor spaces, continue delivery and take-out activities and room service in hotels restaurants, and may engage in catering under contract. In addition, the following conditions must be met in terraces and outdoor spaces:
(1) groups of no more than 10 per table
(2) minimum of one metre (3.3 feet) between tables, or with a screen in between.
(3) masks mandatory at all times for wait and kitchen staff
(4) masks mandatory for customers when not seated
(5) drinking at the counter in bars is prohibited
(6) seated places only (including in bars)
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries
target_other: Mayotte; French Guiana; Paris (Île-de-France); Essonne (Île-de-France); Hauts-de-Seine (Île-de-France); Seine-Saint- Denis (Île-de-France); Seine-et-Marne (Île-de-France); Val-de-Marne (Île-de-France); Val-D’Oise (Île-de-France); Yvelines (Île-de-France)

description: From June 2, 2020 until June 22 in France, in departments designated as orange zones, retail stores and shopping centers with a surface area of greater than 70,000 mˆ2 can open. Masks are recommended for personnel and clients, and these establishments can be closed if rules are not respected. However, the prefect of the department may, after consulting with the mayor, prohibit the opening of a retail store or a shopping center of this size if, due to its location in a heavily populated living area and its immediate proximity to a station served by several rail or guided transport lines and regular public road passenger transport, opening promotes significant population movements.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses

description: From June 2, 2020 until June 22, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has annouced that in green zones, open air establishments for sporting purposes (stadiums, arenas, and horserace tracks) can reopen to practicioners only, and must remain closed to the public. Horserace tracks, stadiums, and arenas can only accomodate the people necessay for the organization of horse races or the practice of physical and sporting activities. These activites must be organzed so that 2 meters distance can be maintained at all times. Masks are mandatory except when engaging in physical activity. Community changing rooms and locker rooms must be closed.

description: On May 31, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-663 which allows closed establishments mentioned in Book II of the Highway Code to welcome the public to dispense the training for the obtention of a driving license if these establishments can't insure this training remotely. A physical distance of at least one meter between two people has to be observed and mask wearing is mandatory for people older than 11 years old. This is to last from June 2, 2020, but no end date has been given.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other government service not specified above
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 31, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-663, which allowed establishments of category L (hearing, conference, meeting, performance or multipurpose rooms) to open in green departments from June 2, 2020 under three conditions (first, mask wearing is mandatory in these establishments for people over 11 years old. Furthermore, the managers of these establishments must ensure that the people welcomed have a seat and that a minimum distance of one seat is left between the seats occupied by each person or each group of less than ten people coming together or having booked together). The same decree prohibited hearing, conference, meeting, performance or multipurpose rooms to open except for courtrooms in orange departments from June 2, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other public facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
2 June 2020, France. Establishments can now open. Following recommendations from medical authority le Haut Conseil de la Santé Publique, the government has not imposed a mandatory four-metre-square limit around each table (as it had previously suggested it might), but restaurants are still required to respect strict rules, including:

10 people maximum per table
At least a metre between tables and groups
Patrons are not allowed to drink or eat standing up at the bar
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
June 1, 2020. All collèges and schools on mainland France will now reopen, as will lycées in green zones.

These will reopen gradually, so not all students will restart classes today.

Masks are mandatory for all students when moving around, and for all staff taking care of children. Teachers, however, do not need to wear a mask “when they are giving a class and are at least one metre away from students”.

All of these rules are set to be re-evaluated from June 22.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Restaurants are required to follow strict rules as: 10 people maximum per table, a metre between tables and groups and patrons are not allowed to drink or eat standing up at bar. Only in orange zones (Ile- de-Frace and over seas territories of Mayotte and French Guiana) only restaurant and bar terraces are allowed to reopen; in Paris restaurants will be permitted to "spead out" into public spaces". Hotels and campsites, so as cultural and sport centres, are open in green zones, in orange zones must wait until june 22. Parks and gardens will reopen in alll zones. Wearing a mask will be mandatory in museums and touristic areas, and physical distancing measure must be respected. Weddings and public gatherings are allowed but phyical distancing measure must remain; public gathering of +10 people aren't allowed until june 21 and +5000 people remain banned until at least August 31.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Paid lodgings (e.g. hotels; motels)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Phase 2 deconfinement in France began on June 2, 2020, with restrictions lifted on bars, cafes, restaurants, travel distances, tourist accommodation, parks, and more. In green zones, bars, cafes, and restaurants have reopened, while in orange zones, only restaurant and bar terraces are permitted to reopen. Hotels, campsites, tourist accommodation such as gites and B&Bs, and holiday villages are now open in green zones, while parks, gardens, forests, watersports centres, lakes, and zoos are now open to the public across the country. Cinemas will stay closed until June 22 everywhere, and weddings in religious sites or Mairies will be allowed.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at All or unspecified businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 31, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-663, which allowed all parks and gardens to reopen as of June 2nd, 2020, regardless of the color of the departments. UPDATE: The original policy allowed the opening of parks and gardens in green departments, but not in red departments. As of June 2nd, 2020 all parks and gardens are allowed to open in France, regardless of the color of the departments.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In France from May 18, 2020, middle schools can reopen in green departments only, starting with sixième (age 11) and cinquième (age 12). Classes sizes are limited to only 15 students per class and masks are mandatory for all faculty and students. UPDATE: The original reopening of middle schools applied to only green departments. However, starting June 2, middle schools will reopen in all departments in France, regardless of color designation.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On May 19, 2020, the Rectorate of the Ile-de-France region of France, with the support of the regional prefect, departmental prefects, state services, ARS (Regional Health Agency) and communities have defined a common protocol for the reopening of schools. It was announced that the health security will be ensured for staff and students through the means of mask wearing, social distancing, classes limited to 15 students, and any student not in school would follow online distanced learning. UPDATE: Starting June 2, 2020, the île-de-France region of France decided that:

- "All primary schools reopen but with reduced numbers, no more than 15 students per class and must ensure a systematic reception of students, at least part of the week.

- Colleges: it is the turn of the 6th and 5th grades to gradually return to college. Masks are mandatory when travelling within establishments.

- Vocational high schools open their doors and general and technological high schools welcome students for individual pedagogical interviews. Masks are mandatory when travelling."

These measures are part of the second phase of deconfinement in the orange zone.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On May 7 2020, the French government confirmed that public tranposrt users in the Île-de-France region will have to present a professional certificate or a compelling reason to travel during rush hour when public tranport re-opens on May 11. 
Permitted reasons include: 
1. Travel for work which cannot be postponed.
2. Travel to school or to an exam.
3. Travel for medical appointments that cannot be completed through video meetings.
4. Travel for urgent family reasons including caring for children or a vulnerable individual.
5. Travel to court or police station UPDATE: Another travel type permitted was added as a compelling reason to travel related to the professional transport certificate.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions ridership of other forms of public transportation (please include details in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On the 19 April 2020, French Health Minister Olivier Véran annouced family members could visit relatives in aged-care facilities again from April 20 2020 with certain conditions had to be respected, including maintaining hand hygiene, wearing a mask, maitining social distancing (1m in between each person), and holding meetings in gardens of designated rooms. UPDATE: The French Ministry of Health and Prevention recommended, on June 6, 2020, "that the management of establishments whose health situation allows it [to] ensure a resumption of visits by relatives.

In addition, it is decided to further relax the applicable instructions. The following are now authorized:

- visits of more than two people at a time, when the visit is not made in a room;
- room visits of up to two people at a time, when security conditions permit;
- visits by minors, provided that they can wear a mask.

In addition, the condition of continuous presence of a professional alongside relatives is terminated.

Finally, it is recalled that the resumption of more medical and paramedical visits and collective activities in very small groups can be decided, as well as the intervention of trained and supervised volunteers. In particular, when the establishment has a garden or courtyard, outdoor activities can be organized (walks, entertainment in very small groups)."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

description: From June 17, 2020, in France, elderly homes that do no report any possible or confirmed COVID-19 cases, must establish plans for a gradual return to "normality" before june 22, 2020. Medical staff in coordination with Établissement d'hébergement pour personnes âgées dépendantes (EHPAD) medics are working together to create these plans. They're going to be presented to the Conseil de la vie sociale CVS on behalf of residents and family. The plans must guarantee the resupmtion of family visits without a date, so as other activities (social life, end of closure on rooms, paramedical intervention and admissions to permanent accommodation and nurseries)
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

description:
"From June 22, 2020 in France, and until further notice, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has annouced that restaurants, bars, cafés, and hotel restaurants can reopen across all of France under the following conditions: 
(1) groups of no more than 10 per table
(2) minimum of one metre (3.3 feet) between tables, or with a screen in between.
(3) masks mandatory at all times for wait and kitchen staff
(4) masks mandatory for customers when not seated
(5) drinking at the counter in bars is prohibited
(6) seated places only (including in bars)
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On July 10, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-860, which extended the opening of establishments of category L (hearing, conference, projection, meeting, performance or multipurpose rooms) in the territories that have emerged from the public health emergency. However, the managers of these establishments must ensure that the people welcomed have a seat and that a minimum distance of one seat is left between the seats occupied by each person or each group of less than ten people coming together or having booked together. Mask wearing is mandatory for people older than 11 years old. The same decree prohibited hearing, conference, projection, meeting, performance or multipurpose rooms to reopen in the territories where the state of emergency is still in force (Guyane and Mayotte).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other public facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On July 10, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-860, which allows campsites and trailer parks to welcome the public in territories that have emerged from the health emergency as of July 11, 2020. A physical distance of at least one meter between two people must be observed at all times, but if it is not possible mask wearing is mandatory. This decree also forbids campsites and trailer parks to welcome the public in territories where the health emergency is still in force (Guyane and Mayotte) except for those that are considered permanent homes for the people who live there (Category PA).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Campsites
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On July 10, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-860, which allows establishments mentioned in Book II of the Highway Code to welcome the public to dispense the training for the obtention of a driving license if these establishments can't insure this training remotely. A physical distance of at least one meter between two people has to be observed and mask wearing is mandatory for people older than 11 years old. This is to last from July 11, 2020, but no end date has been given. UPDATE: The original policy allowed closed establishments mentioned in Book II of the Highway Code to welcome the public to dispense the training for the obtention of a driving license if these establishments can't insure this training remotely from June 2, 2020. On July 10, 2020 it was extended, but no end date was given.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
France. August 3rd, 2020.
Wearing a mask in certain outdoor public spaces has been made mandatory in some French towns and cities. In Nice, the mayor has declared that everyone is required to wear a mask in many areas of the southern French city, including parts of the famous Promenade des Anglais. Masks now have to be worn in 69 towns in Mayenne, in the north-west of France, where data has shown the virus is actively circulating. Biarritz, Bayonne, Saint-Malo, Le Touquet and Orleans have also imposed face coverings in the centre of town and in outdoor markets.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
On August 7 2020, the Prefect of the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France announced that the wearing of masks was compulsory in certain areas of the city of Marseille from August 8 2020 to August 30 2020. 
The following areas were specified: Vieux-Port - hyper-centre (masks mandatory in some locations  from 10am to 4am of each day), Éscale Borely (masks mandatory in one location from 7pm to 4am of every day), and Cours Julien - La Plaine (masks mandatory in some locations from 7pm to 4am of every day). People with a certified medical exemption were exempt from this policy. 
This policy was undertaken with the cooperation of the Mayor of Marseille, and the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the PACA region. 
This mandate was made in accordance with French national legislation from 10 July 2020, which authorised local governments to create and enforce mask mandates.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: On August 24 2020, the Department of Hauts-de-Seine in the Île-de-France region of France announced in a prefectural decree that the wearing of masks will be compulsory in all the streets in the cities of Boulogne-Billancourt and Sceaux and not in specified sectors, in order to contain the circulation of the coronavirus. It concerns all people over 11 years old and could be punished with a 135 euros fine if not respected. UPDATE: The policy was repealed on August 27 2020 and replaced with a mask wearing mandate with new exemptions that extended to include pedestrians, cyclists, drivers of scooters and two wheelers, and anyone walking around outside Paris and the inner suburbs (la petite couronne) by the police prefecture and the prefects of Seine-Saint-Denis, Hauts -de-Seine and Val-de-Marne.

description: In the city of Paris in the region of France, the police prefect, in consultation with the Mayor of Paris, makes it compulsory to wear a mask from Friday, August 28 2020 at 8 a.m. onwards in all of Paris and in the inner suburbs (Seine-Saint-Denis, Hauts-de-Seine and the Val-de-Marne). The measure concerns pedestrians, but also cyclists, drivers of scooters and steps. Anyone walking around unprotected without a mask incurs a fine of 135 euros. UPDATE: On the same day it was decided that, according to a second press release issued by the Paris police headquarters, people who circulate by bicycle or those who practice running will be exempt from the compulsory wearing of a mask.

description: From 8 August to 31 August 2020, the department of Aube in the Grand Est region of France decreed that masks are compulsory in public spaces within a certain perimeter in the city of Troyes every day from 11am to 1:30am the following morning for persons aged 11 and over. Those with justifying medical certificates are exempted. Offences are punishable by fine of 135 euros. UPDATE: the department of Aube has extended the policy until September 30th 2020. The perimeter (also known as the "Bouchon de Champagne") within which masks are compulsory has been expanded, along with hours of compliance from 7am to 3am the following day. UPDATE: The original mask wearing policy did not have an end date, it has now been extended and set to September 30th.

description:
On September 5 2020, the Prefect of the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France decreed a policy of compulsory mask-wearing to the entire department of Bouches-du-Rhone. From September 5 2020 to September 30 2020, mask-wearing was made compulsory for all people aged 11 and over from 6am to 2am in all urban public spaces. People with medical exemptions (in the form of certificates), cyclists, and those playing outdoor sport were exempt from the policy. 
This policy was made in cooperation with the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the PACA region, as well as the Chief of Police of the PACA region.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

Mask wearing was also recommended in workplaces and remote working was encouraged. People with a medical exemption were exempt from this policy. This policy was made in accordance with the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of PACA, and the Chief of Police for the Department of Bouches-de-Rhone. description: On Septemeber 5, 2020, the Prefect of the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France repealed this decree and replaced it with new restrictions and regulations of businesses from September 27, 2020 until October 11, 2020. Bars, restaurants, cafes and general food stores remain closed from 12:30 a.m. to 6:00 a.m.  A multiplication of controls and strengthening of sanctions was also legislated: including a procedure for the systematic closure of all establishments open to the public which do not ensure their customers' respect for social distancing was planned, and a ban on refreshments and other standing catering points.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: On October 5 2020, the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France announced the reopening of restaurants in Aix-en-Provence and Marseille. There are restrictions to respect :  - a ban on consumption while standing indoors or outdoors  - a distance of at least one meter between each chair -limit of the number of guests at the same table to six - obligation to wear a mask  -the maximum reception capacity respecting the measures mentioned  - set up a “reminder book” in order to keep the contact details of customers available to health authorities (14 days max).
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: From 6 October in the morning until 19 October inclusive, there were certain restrictions in Ile-de-France. It includes the closure of all bars, limits restaurant occupancy, prohibits the takeaway sale of alcohol and the consumption of alcohol on public roads from 10 p.m., and prohibits student, wedding, or other private festivities. Additionally, announces the closure of game clubs, dance halls, and game rooms, as well as fairs, exhibitions, and events held in large tents.

description:
On October 11 2020, the Prefect of the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France decreed that the wearing of masks to would be compulsory for all residents of all communes in the department, but with some specific rules. 
In all communes except Marseille and Aix-en-Provence, masks were mader compulsory from 6am to 2am in markets, within 50m of commercial areas and schools, and in public transport waiting areas, until October 27 2020. 
In the communes of Marseille and Aix-en-Provence, masks were made compulsory in all public spaces until October 27 2020.

description: On October 16, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1262, which authorized establishments of category L (hearing, conference, projection, meeting, performance or multipurpose rooms) to open in all territories of France. However, the managers of these establishments must ensure that the people welcomed have a seat and that a minimum distance of one seat is left between the seats occupied by each person or each group of less than ten people coming together or having booked together. Mask wearing is mandatory for people older than 11 years old.
