description: On October 16, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1262, which establishes new conditions for the opening of large museums. Mask wearing is still mandatory for people older than 11 years old. However, museums cannot admit more people than the number of people required so that each person has a 4 square meter space. In addition, when local circumstances justify it, the prefect of a department may limit the maximum number of people who can be admitted in these establishments.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On October 16th, 2020, French government imposed several measures that must be observed throughout France: 
-Social distancing of 1 metter; social gatherings must follow these measures, if activity doesn't force to wear mask, admin. can decide to force it or not; if not wearing a mask, distancing must be of 2 metters  
-People aged 11 or over must present a negative screening examination carried out less than 72 hours before crossing or travel by public air transport, so as a sworn statements attesting doesn't have symptoms, haven´t been in contact with a confirmed case in the 14 days preceding the flight, accepting an examination can be carried out on his arrival, and undertakes to respect a prophylatic isolation of 7 days.  
-Any person aged eleven or over who accessses or remains in vehicles or in spaced accesibel to public and assigned to public transport wears a protective mask.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On October 16, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1262, which establishes new conditions for the opening of large museums. Mask wearing is still mandatory for people older than 11 years old. However, museums cannot admit more people than the number of people required so that each person has a ​​4 square meter space. In addition, when local circumstances justify it, the prefect of a department may limit the maximum number of people who can be admitted in these establishments. UPDATE: The original policy allowed large museums to welcome the public. Mask wearing was mandatory for people older than 11 years old. However, museums cannot admit more people than the number of people required so that each person has a ​​4 square meter space. description: On October 16, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1262, which allows establishments mentioned in Book II of the Highway Code to welcome the public to dispense the training for the obtention of a driving license if these establishments can't insure this training remotely. A physical distance of at least one meter between two people has to be observed and mask wearing is mandatory for people older than 11 years old. This is to last from October 16, 2020, but no end date has been given. UPDATE: The original policy allowed closed establishments mentioned in Book II of the Highway Code to welcome the public to dispense the training for the obtention of a driving license if these establishments can't insure this training remotely from June 2, 2020. On July 10, 2020 it was extended, but no end date was given. On October 16, 2020, it was extended again, but no end date was given.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
On October 11 2020, the Prefect of the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France decreed that the wearing of masks to would be compulsory for all residents of all communes in the department, but with some specific rules. 
In all communes except Marseille and Aix-en-Provence, masks were mader compulsory from 6am to 2am in markets, within 50m of commercial areas and schools, and in public transport waiting areas, until October 27 2020. 
In the communes of Marseille and Aix-en-Provence, masks were made compulsory in all public spaces until October 27 2020. UPDATE: On October 17 2020, the Prefect of the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France repealed the policy of October 11 2020 and made conditions surrounding mask-wearing the same in all communes.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: On October 20 2020, the Prefect of the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France repealed the policy of October 17 2020 and replaced it with a new set of mask wearing rules. In the communes of Marseille and Aix-en-Provence, masks were made compulsory in all spaces open to the public from 6am to 2am every day. In all other communes in the department, masks remained compulsory from 6am to 2am only in markets, within 50m of commercial areas of schools, and in public transport waiting areas. Both policies carried a new exemption of people in areas classed as 'natural zones' (nature areas), alongside the previously stated exemptions (cyclists, medical reasons, and outdoor sport).

Masks are mandatory except during the practice of physical activity, and sanitary health and safety rules apply. UPDATE: The original policy allowed closed establishments mentioned in Book II of the Highway Code to welcome the public to dispense the training for the obtention of a driving license if these establishments can't insure this training remotely from June 2, 2020. On July 10, 2020 it was extended, but no end date was given. On October 16, 2020, it was extended again, but no end date was given. On October 19, 2020, it was extended again at least until December 1st, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Other government service not specified above
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 29, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1320, which forbids campsites and trailer parks to welcome the public except when they constitute a permanent home for the people who live there. This is to last from October 30, 2020 until at least December 1, 2020. UPDATE: The original policy allowed campsites and trailer parks to be open in all departments of France. From October 30, 2020 and at least December 1, 2020, campsites and trailer parks can no longer welcome the public except when they constitute a permanent home for the people who live there.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Campsites
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 29, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1310, which forbids large museums and rooms intended for temporarily cultural exhibitions to open to the public. This is to last from October 30, 2020 until at least December 1, 2020. UPDATE: The original policy established new conditions for the opening of large museums in France. On October 29, 2020, it was decided that all large museums and rooms intended for temporarily cultural exhibitions could no longer welcome the public. This is to last from October 30, 2020 until at least December 1, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
"From June 22, 2020 in France, and until further notice, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has annouced that restaurants, bars, cafés, and hotel restaurants can reopen across all of France under the following conditions: 
(1) groups of no more than 10 per table
(2) minimum of one metre (3.3 feet) between tables, or with a screen in between.
(3) masks mandatory at all times for wait and kitchen staff
(4) masks mandatory for customers when not seated
(5) drinking at the counter in bars is prohibited
(6) seated places only (including in bars) UPDATE: From October 30, 2020, most establishments open to the public will be closed: bars and restaurants, shops other than those of first necessity, multi-purpose halls, conference rooms, performance halls and cinemas, sports halls, amusement parks, trade fairs, fairs and exhibitions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 28th of August 2020, In France, the prefect of the department of Gironde has issued an order targeting 2 cities located in Gironde. The 2 cities are Bordeaux and Bouliac. This new policy makes wearing a mask mandatory for all people aged eleven years old and above, in areas with a high population density. UPDATE: The last policy update was ending on the 30th of October but this order extends its duration.

description: On October 20 2020, the Prefect of the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France repealed the policy of October 17 2020 and replaced it with a new set of mask wearing rules. In the communes of Marseille and Aix-en-Provence, masks were made compulsory in all spaces open to the public from 6am to 2am every day. In all other communes in the department, masks remained compulsory from 6am to 2am only in markets, within 50m of commercial areas of schools, and in public transport waiting areas. Both policies carried a new exemption of people in areas classed as 'natural zones' (nature areas), alongside the previously stated exemptions (cyclists, medical reasons, and outdoor sport). UPDATE: On October 30 2020, the Prefect of the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France declared that the wearing of masks was now compulsory in all spaces open to the public in all communes in the department until December 1 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On October 17th 2020, the department of Aube located in the Grand Est region of France implemented a mandatory mask wearing order for all pedestrians aged 11 years and older, in public spaces with a high concentration of people. This order applies everyday from 7AM to 3 AM next morning. This policy starts October 17th 2020 and ends November 14th 2020. UPDATE : On October 30th 2020 the policy is extended until December 1st 2020. UPDATE: The original curfew was set to last until November 14th, it has been extended to December 1st 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On November 27, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1454, which allows librairies, documentation centers and archive preservation centers to welcome the public as of November 28, 2020, but no end date has been given. The managers of these establishments must ensure that a minimum distance of one seat is left between the seats occupied by each person or each group of less than six people coming together or having booked together. Mask wearing is mandatory for people older than 11 years old.

description:
On December 12th, 2020, French government announced a policy for long term care facilities for the elderly (EHPAD - établissements d'hébergement pour personnes âgées dépendantes) that includes the following guidelines:  
o Strict hygiene measures (masks, handwashing, social distancing, disinfection,   
o Visits are allowed, but all visitors have to take a COVID-19  test or an antigen test 72 hours before the visit, and to fill in a COVID-19-related questionnaire to establish the risk of entering the facility.   
oVisits should only take place in outside spaces.  oLimit visits to families to exceptional circumstances              
Note: from 15 Dec, to alleviate feelings of loneliness during the Christmas and New Year’s season, elderly care residents will be able to receive visitors in their rooms and leave their residence in the period between 15th Dec and 3rd Jan. On returning to their facility, they will have to take a Covid-19 test (PCR or antigen). And cannot participate in group activities for 7 days after their return.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

description:
France, December 15th, 2020
With regard to visits by relatives to establishments housing elderly people and long-term care units, the conditions remain regulated visits by appointment. However, an increase in the gauges  number of visitors per resident and maximum number of visitors welcomed simultaneously by appointment slot  and in the duration of the appointment slots may be considered in order to facilitate the organization of visits and allow families to meet in more friendly conditions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:

Visits are allowed, but all visitors have to take a COVID-19  test or an antigen test 72 hours before the visit, and to fill in a COVID-19-related questionnaire to establish the risk of entering the facility. Visits should only take place in outside spaces. Limit visits to families to exceptional circumstances UPDATE: "France, December 15th, 2020
With regard to visits by relatives to establishments housing elderly people and long-term care units, the conditions remain regulated visits by appointment. France, December 23rd, 2020
A growing number of French cities now require cloth face coverings in outdoor areas throughout or in designated parts of the city. This includes Paris and its suburbs, where cloth face coverings are required in all outdoor locations. Rules vary by city and can change quickly.

description: According to the Minister of Education of France, from January 14, 2021, the government would roll out a mass-testing scheme in schools, testing up to one million pupils and teachers each month: "Every time there are three cases (discovered), a screening team will be sent to the premises". In the canteens, pupils in the same class will eat together every day and at the same table. High school pupils in terminale (third and final year) would have to be present “as much as possible”. The government announced that all indoor sports were temporarily suspended. This includes out-of-school activities. First-year university students will be authorised to return to their courses on-site, but with reduced numbers of participants, from January 25th.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 30 2020, the Prefect of the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France declared that the wearing of masks was now compulsory in all spaces open to the public in all communes in the department until December 1 2020. Exemptions were in place for certified medical reasons, cyclists, and outdoor sports. UPDATE: On January 15 2021, the Prefect of the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France extended the policy mandating the wearing of masks in all spaces open to the public in all communes in the department until March 1 2021. Exemptions remained for certified medical reasons, cyclists, and outdoor sports.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On October 16th, 2020, French government announced several measures that must be observed: 
-Social distancing of 1 metter; social gatherings must follow these measures, if activity doesn't force to wear mask, admin. can decide to force it or not; if not wearing a mask, distancing must be of 2 metters  
-People aged 11 or over must present a negative screening examination carried out less than 72 hours before crossing or travel by public air transport, so as a sworn statements attesting doesn't have symptoms, haven´t been in contact with a confirmed case in the 14 days preceding the flight, accepting an examination can be carried out on his arrival, and undertakes to respect a prophylatic isolation of 7 days.  
-Any person aged eleven or over who accessses or remains in vehicles or in spaced accesibel to public and assigned to public transport wears a protective mask. UPDATE: From January 27th, 2020, in France, President Macron announced that physical distancing between 2 people must be of at least 2 metters.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Several measures must be observed throughout France: 
-Social distancing of 1 metter; social gatherings must follow these measures, if activity doesn't force to wear mask, admin. can decide to force it or not; if not wearing a mask, distancing must be of 2 metters  
-People aged 11 or over must present a negative screening examination carried out less than 72 hours before crossing or travel by public air transport, so as a sworn statements attesting doesn't have symptoms, haven´t been in contact with a confirmed case in the 14 days preceding the flight, accepting an examination can be carried out on his arrival, and undertakes to respect a prophylatic isolation of 7 days.  
-Any person aged eleven or over who accessses or remains in vehicles or in spaced accesibel to public and assigned to public transport wears a protective mask. UPDATE: President Macron announced that social distancing between 2 people must be of at least 2 metters, not 1.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On November 16th 2020, the Department of Bas-Rhin in the Grand Est region of France extended a national mask mandate for pedestrians aged 11 years and older, in the city of Strasbourg and all the other cities of Bas-Rhin. Wearing a mask is mandatory in transports and in public spaces except the forests, natural reserves, ports and the surrounding area of Strasbourg. This policy is set to end December 15th 2020. UPDATE: This policy has been extended on February 16th 2021 in the Department of Bas Rhin, which is located in the Grand Est region of France, until March 17th 2021. UPDATE: The original mask wearing policy was set to last until December 15th 2020, it has been extended to March 17th 2021

description: According to the Minister of Education of France, from January 14, 2021, the government would roll out a mass-testing scheme in schools, testing up to one million pupils and teachers each month: "Every time there are three cases (discovered), a screening team will be sent to the premises". In the canteens, pupils in the same class will eat together every day and at the same table. High school pupils in terminale (third and final year) would have to be present “as much as possible”. The government announced that all indoor sports were temporarily suspended. This includes out-of-school activities. First-year university students will be authorised to return to their courses on-site, but with reduced numbers of participants, from January 25th. UPDATE: The government announced on Saturday, 20 March 2021, that, for at least a month, primary schools and colleges (ages 11-15) will stay open as normal, but high schools (ages 16-18) will switch back to a hybrid half-at-home, half-at-school schedule.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 30 2020, the Prefect of the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France declared that the wearing of masks was now compulsory in all spaces open to the public in all communes in the department until December 1 2020. Exemptions were in place for certified medical reasons, cyclists, and outdoor sports. UPDATE: On May 3 2021, the Prefect of the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France extended the policy mandating the wearing of masks in all spaces open to the public in all communes in the department until May 18 2021. Exemptions remained for certified medical reasons, cyclists, and outdoor sports.

description: On May 2021, the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France announced new regulations of businesses. Activities relating to the rental of beach equipment and the sale of take-out catering are prohibited. Nautical activities and pleasure boating are authorized on condition of respecting on the one hand the general police measures, hygiene and social distancing measures, specific organizational arrangements. Scuba diving clubs' activities and commercial companies that rent pleasure botas or realize commercial services using boats for commercial use can reopen subject to strict compliance with the measures.

description:
France, June 30th, 2021
Throughout France, masks are required in schools, in places where social distancing cannot be maintained, or at public events with a capacity of less than 1000 people where the Health Pass is not in use. When use of the Health Pass is required, masks are recommended but not mandatory.     Within the Landes department, face masks are required in high traffic areas in nominated tourist regions until at least 21 July, due to prevalence of the Delta variant COVID-19 virus.

description:
France, July 12th, 2021
Outside protections afforded to the general population, visits to EHPAD long-term care homes are required to make use of barrier protection methods. From "early August", the Government proposes that use of the Health Pass will be required for all visitors to long-term care homes, and that from 15 September, all people working with "frail people" will need to be vaccinated.

description: Since July 21, 2021, French government imposed a new protocol in Établissement d'hébergement pour personnes âgées dépendantes  (EHPAD) and nursing homes provides that: measures implemented to protect residents are the same as in the general population; visits of relatives can be made without appointment in room as in the collective spaces; It is no longer required to complete a self-assessment upon arrival. The traceability register is maintained; Exits are allowed, without limitation of collective activities on return (except in case of contact at risk), but by maintaining screening for unvaccinated residents; Day receptions are normally open. Family visits can now be made without an appointment, in rooms as in collective spaces. They will be organized so that distancing is respected with other residents/families of residents. Vaccination is mandatory for all persons in contact with frail persons (caregivers, non-caregivers, professionals and volunteers).
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

The traceability register is maintained; Exits are allowed, without limitation of collective activities on return (except in case of contact at risk), but by maintaining screening for unvaccinated residents; Day receptions are normally open. Family visits can now be made without an appointment, in rooms as in collective spaces. They will be organized so that distancing is respected with other residents/families of residents. Vaccination is mandatory for all persons in contact with frail persons (caregivers, non-caregivers, professionals and volunteers).

description: On July 28, 2021, the Minister for National Education of France announced a new policy for middle and high schools to be implemented from the start of the new school year on September 2. A four-tier system of restrictions will be in place with controls depending on the incidence of COVID-19. Level 1 (Green): In-person learning at all levels. Level 2 (Yellow): In-person learning at all levels. Level 3 (Orange): In-person learning at primary and middle schools, hybrid learning (alternating distance and in-person learning) in high schools. Level 4 (Red): In-person learning in primary schools, hybrid learning for 50% of 3rd year, all 4th year and high school students. Increasing levels of sanitary requirements, mask-wearing, restrictions on sports, and protocols for contact tracing will be applied at each level.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: June 3, 2020: The Government of the Netherlands announced that “France, Germany, Italy and the Netherlands are joining forces in negotiations with potential developers and manufacturers of a coronavirus vaccine. Together, the 4 countries are exploring promising vaccine initiatives and are in discussions with a number of pharmaceutical companies. They intend to have the vaccines manufactured in Europe if possible.” Therefore, the 4 countries have “agreed to form the ‘Inclusive Vaccine Alliance’. According to the alliance, one of the most urgent matters at hand is to accelerate the development process and ensure global access to an effective vaccine.”
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: June 13, 2020: With Bulletin N. 191, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Ministers of Health of Italy, Germany, France and The Netherlands, after recently launching the vaccine alliance, signed a contract with AstraZeneca for the supply of 400 million doses of vaccines for the entire European population.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: One June 16 2020, the Minister for Solidarity and Health of France , Olivier Véran, and the Secretary of State to the Minister for the Economy and Finance, Agnès Pannier-Runacher, announce the signing of a first Alliance agreement for the purchase of vaccines against SARS-CoV-2.The AstraZeneca laboratory, if its project is successful, will provide the Alliance(France,Germany, Italy and the Netherlands) with up to 400 million doses of vaccine at cost price.If ongoing clinical trials confirm the efficacy and safety of use of the candidate vaccine, these volumes will make it possible to vaccinate at-risk populations throughout the European Union.

description: On January 31, 2020 the Federal Office of Foreign Affairs of Switzerland informed at its press conference, that the Swiss authorities are not planning their own repatriation operation for Swiss citizens from Hubai Province in China. The Flight back is organized together with France. The plan is for the flight from China to France to head for the port city of Marseille. On February 7 it was confirmet that the Swiss citizens and their family returned on the evacuation flight on February 3. The FDFA would help with the return to Switzerland after the end of the 14 day quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
